text: On an expanse of water, calm and undisturbed. After a mom it begins to ripple as something rises toward the surface girl's face breaks through.
It wasn't a murder. I think God just  died of old age. And when I realized  He wasn't any more, it didn't shock  me. It seemed natural and right.

The girl, FRANCES, is 16, blond, very pretty: she seems l the most persuasive proof imaginable of God's existence. swims toward the shore with long graceful strokes... then climbs the steps of the old wood jetty on West Point Beac
And yet I began to wonder what the  minister meant when he said, 'God,  the Father, sees even the smallest  sparrow fall. He watches over all  his children.' That jumbled it all  up for me.
The banks of Puget Sound, dotted with elm trees. Frances  sits comfortably in the fork of a tree writing in her dia Towel around her neck, her hair splayed out and drying go in the sun.
But still sometimes I found that God  was useful to remember, especially  when I lost things that were  important. 'Please God, let me find  my red hat with the blue trimmings.'

Frances is now reading aloud from her diary, gently swayi back and forth in a rocking chair. An older woman, LILLIA FARMER, sits opposite on the couch, listening and nodding from time to time. A small suitcase stands by the front d
It usually worked. God became a  superfather that couldn't spank me.  But if I wanted a thing badly enough,  He arranged it.
ERNEST FARMER appears in the doorway and hesitates, liste to his daughter read.
But if God loved all of His children  equally, why did He bother about my  red hat and let other people lose  their fathers and mothers for always?
Ernest goes to Frances and kisses her softly on the top o her head. She looks at him briefly, smiling slightly.
Bye, baby.
See you next weekend, Dad.
He goes to the door and picks up his suitcase, glances at Lillian. She doesn't look up. He leaves.
I began to see that He didn't have  much to do about hats or people dying  or anything. They happened whether  He wanted them to or not, and He  stayed in Heaven and pretended not  to notice.

Frances stands at a podium. Other STUDENTS and TEACHERS s to either side of her on folding chairs. Above the prosce is engraved: West Seattle High School. Below that a banne hangs: "NATIONAL HIGH SCHOOL ESSAY COMPETITION, 1931."
I wondered a little why God was such  a useless thing. It seemed a waste  of time to have Him. After that He  became less and less, until He was...  nothingness.

The AUDIENCE consists of parents, students, and local  dignitaries. We SEE several shocked faces. Lillian is the also, smiling. Seated next to her is a distinguished-look woman, ALMA STYLES. Ernest sits on the other side of the  auditorium, looking a little worried.

I felt rather proud that I had found  the truth myself, without help from  anyone. It puzzled me that other  people hadn't found out, too. God  was gone. We had reached past Him.  Why couldn't they see it? It still  puzzles me.

Frances closes her notebook and looks up, waiting for som response. There is a deep shocked silence, then a smatter of applause. Lillian claps enthusiastically, then rises t her feet. In the back a WOMAN also stands.
You're going straight to hell, Frances  Farmer!
A stately man sitting next to her, her husband JUDGE BENJ HILLIER, puts a restraining hand on her arm. The woman  continues to glare at Frances. Frances stares back, dumbfounded.

The screen erupts into violence. A large unruly MOB skirm with POLICE in a cobblestoned square. On a truckbed addre the crowd -- which carries placards reading: "Organize No "Workers of the World Unite!", and "Elect Kaminski!" stan MARTONI KAMINSKI. By his side, leading the crowd's respon stands a younger man with sharp piercing eyes, HARRY YORK
And do you think it's radical for a  man to have a job and feed a family?
No!
Is it radical for you to have a hand  in shaping your future, and the future  of your children?
No!
Is it radical for the wealth of this  country to be turned back to the  people who built the country?
No! No!
Good! Because, Brothers, that's you!
The crowd cheers. Harry York gives Kaminski the thumbs-up sign as a banner unfurls: "Today Seattle -- Tomorrow the  World."
We realize we've been watching a newsreel. We SEE the SCH SUPERINTENDENT presenting Frances with an award.
Seattle is in the news again as a  high school junior wins a national  competition and a hundred dollar  prize with an essay denying God.
City Hall steps. Judge Hillier and other BIGWIGS speaking heatedly to reporters.
This prompts civic officials to charge  that left-wing politicians are  encouraging atheism in the city's  schools. Miss Frances Farmer was  unavailable for comment, but her  mother Lillian --
Lillian stands in front of her wood frame house addressin small CROWD of reporters, photographers, and curious  neighbors.
Farmer, a well-known local dietician,  stepped to her daughter's defense.

(emphatically) Frances has not turned her back on  the Lord, they're just having a  momentary difference of opinion.  What child hasn't questioned the  Lord's mysteries in order to better  understand them? To paraphrase Mr.  Voltaire, I may not agree with what  she says, but I'll defend to the  death her right to say it. Freedom  of speech, unlike in the dark  countries to the east, still lives  in America! And in my home.
Among the AUDIENCE in the cinema, we SEE Frances and her  father. Frances slinks down in her seat until she's hidde from sight.

Frances carries library books and a small grocery bag. He hair and skin gleam in the sun. People in their yards sta at her as she passes. She walks on, coming to a group of  CHILDREN slightly younger than herself who are playing in front of a union hall. A girl, EMMA, 13, glances up.
Hi Emma.
Emma looks away quickly, returns to her play.
Bye Emma.
Frances shakes her head as she walks on.
Hey!
Frances hesitates, then turns to look: A man in his twenties whom we recognize as Harry York,  Kaminski's compatriot, leaves a group of men in front of union hall and walks toward her.
(friendly) C'mere. I wanna talk to you.
Frances keeps walking. Harry hurries after her.
Momma told ya not to speak to  strangers, huh? (reaches her, grabs  her arm) Hey!
Don't touch me.
I'm not gonna hurt you. I just wanna  talk.
She stares at him. He's got a newspaper wedged under one  arm.
(waiting) Okay then...
Well... you're causin' trouble, you  know that?
I'm causing trouble?! You're a pain  in the butt! You newshounds've been  after me and my folks ever since I  won that dumb contest. I'm just  sixteen, you know? Who the hell cares  what I think?
Not me. But other people seem to.
Yeah. Well if you didn't put it in  the papers -- nobody'd even know  about it.
Now wait a minute, sweetie. Do I  look like a newshound to you?
(examining him) No... Actually, you look more like a  cop.
Harry laughs.
That's rich. Hey, if I was a cop,  I'd be packing, right? (holding coat open) You see a gun? Go on, search me. Pat  me down.
Frances hesitates, leans toward him as though about to fr him. Their eyes meet, and she pulls away, suddenly  embarrassed.
I'll... take your word for it. So  who are you, then?
Harry York. I work for Martoni  Kaminski, he's running for Congress  here.
(smiles & points to  him) Oh yeah! I saw you in the newsreel!
(embarrassed) Yeah, well --
You know, my Dad's done some work  for Kaminski...
Now you're catchin' on. Don't wanna  get your Daddy in hot water, do you?
Whattaya mean?
Well... see the papers've got us  pegged as pinkos, then you come along,  the friendly neighborhood atheist --
But I'm not. The newspapers're --
Right again. You're no more an atheist  than my man's a Red, but what they're  doin', see, they're addin' up their  version of your ideas with their  version of ours. Could look bad for  your Daddy.
Yeah. Could look bad for you and  Kaminski too, I guess.
Beat.
Sure don't talk like you're sixteen.
Well aren't you the smoothie. Now  you're going to ask for my number, I  suppose.
I suppose not. Gotta ask you this,  though: for all our sakes, you better  keep your trap shut.
Well... I'll give it a try, Mr. York.
Harry.
(hesitates, nods) Harry.
They half-smile, awkwardly, as if neither really wants th encounter to end. Then Harry doffs his hat.
Bye.
She nods shyly and starts up the path toward the house.
(admiring her) Sure don't walk like sixteen, neither.
CLOSE ON Judge Hillier in his robes, identified by a name on the bench.
These are perilous times. With the  economic collapse comes hopelessness  and desperation; and people turn to  dangerous ideas --
I know.
The CAMERA PULLS SLOWLY BACK. We SEE that the courtroom i empty.
Those of us who represent law and  order must be vigilant. Who's behind  this, her mother?
Now we SEE who he's talking to: Alma Styles, the woman wh sat with Lillian at the school auditorium.
Impossible. As her attorney, I've  known her for years.
What about the father, he's a little  pink. Maybe he wants to show our  schools in a bad light, shift some  support to Kaminski and those jackals.
(shaking her head) He's no influence; he doesn't even  live at home. No, I think Frances  wrote that essay with no mischief  intended. It was her teacher who  entered it in the competition.
Well, the publicity must stop. It's  no good for Seattle and no good for  the country. (sternly) Keep an eye on this, will you, Alma?
Of course, your honor.
He nods with satisfaction. Two right-thinking people figh for what they believe in.

Ernest Farmer sits alone, motionless, at the table. Betwe two candles, facing him, is Frances' check for a hundred  dollars. We HEAR bustle from behind the kitchen door, then Lillian and Frances enter juggling several hot dishes. Ernest ris They set down the dishes, Frances intentionally placing t bread between the check and her father.
It always amazes me, Lil, how you  can whip up a hot, hearty meal out  of thin air.
I can thank you for that. It was a  hard-earned talent.
She moves the bread so Ernest again faces the check. As  Lillian slices the bread, father and daughter eat grimly.
(offering to Ernest) Bread?
(taking a piece) Thank you.
When's the last time you saw a hundred  dollars, Ernest Farmer?
Mama...
(pushing back her  plate) I'm not hungry. You two just enjoy  yourselves. After all, this is a  celebration.
She leaves. A long silence. They both glance slightly awkwardly at the check. Frances takes it, folds it, and puts it in her pocket, ou of sight.
I'm... I'm really proud of you,  Frances.
Thanks, Dad.
An essay contest... a national  contest. That's pretty impressive.
I didn't have much to do with it.
You wrote it, didn't you?
Yeah, I suppose... Dad, who's Harry  York?
Well, Harry York is a guy who...  well, he does a lot of things. Why  do you ask?
He talked to me today. Told me to  keep my mouth shut or I'd get  everybody in trouble.

Yeah... well... it's possible. Harry  York and I both work for Mr. Kaminski  right now, and... well... There are  lots of folks in this country who  never got a square break. That's the  way of things, but Mr. Kaminski wants  to change it, and when it comes to  new ideas, the people in power get  nervous.
Is Kaminski a Communist?
No, no, no. All he wants to do is  see the common man get a little  representation.
He's a socialist, then?

Sitting at a rolltop desk. She's looking through a large  scrapbook. We SEE articles about nutrition and diet, some featuring Lillian's picture, others with her name in the  heading. She listens to the conversation in the other roo

The label's not important, Francie.  What's important is: this country's  got nine million unemployed and  something's gotta be done about it.  Besides: left-wing, right-wing, up- wing, down-wing... they don't mean  much. All a label is usually is a  way to call somebody a dirty name.
Lillian's face becomes set. She looks down at the book. A article titled "Girl Denies God" is there, freshly pasted She lays a hand on the blank page opposite.
It's already started, Dad... with  me.
I know.
And I can't understand how it can  hurt to be honest, but the more I  tried to explain --  (what I meant)
Lillian appears in the doorway.
Don't listen to him, little sister.  When you're proud of what you are,  you don't refuse the label,  understand?
Yes, Ma.
And you... should be proud. You won  that contest and made a name for  yourself.
She stomps out. Frances and Ernest push back their plates
Lillian is watering tomatoes in the dark and talking to t quietly. As Ernest approaches, she senses him and grows  silent. She speaks without turning around.
You're poisoning that child's mind.
I have a right to talk to her. She's  my daughter, and she's beginning to  understand why I've sacrificed so  much in order to achieve...
You've sacrificed?! If you'd practice  law for decent folk instead of  Communists and indigents --
They need help, Lil. They pay me  back in other ways.
How? What do they do for you, Kaminski  and his friends? They're all  anarchists! Traitors!
(sadly) No, Lil. It's just you can't  understand their brand of patriotism.
That's right. I can't understand a  man who puts strangers over his  family, a man who gives up a good  career to become a shiftless inkhorn  failure.
Beat.
I'm going back to the hotel.
Good.
See you next weekend?
As usual. Everything as usual, Mr.  Farmer. Just give me my due.
Ernest starts back toward the house. He sees Frances watc them and slows down, turns...
Lillian... I'm more than willing to  meet you halfway.
Don't make me sick. I'd sooner drown  myself in Puget Sound.
(under his breath) That's a thought, Lil. That sure is  a thought.
He trudges back toward the house under Frances' eye. A WOMAN'S VOICE comes from behind the fence.
Are you all right, dear?
I'm fine, perfectly fine.
Ernest stands on the porch holding his little bag.
Dad, please, don't leave early. Just  because of Mama --
Francie, you'll learn that sometimes  it's best to stay low and just walk  away.
He trudges out and down the walk. Frances watches him, shaking her head. That is not a less she wants to learn.

Opening night. Harry is reading a playbill displayed in a theatre lobby: "1934 Spring Production... University of  Washington Players Present: 'Uncle Vanya' by Anton Chekho Frances is playing Sonia. Harry turns and enters the thea
Frances on stage seen from a distance.
What can we do, we must live! We  shall live, Uncle Vanya...
Frances is acting with a nervous young man, CHET. As her  speech progresses, the camera moves in nearer and nearer, ending with a close-up. It is as if we are being drawn in her emotion.

And then we shall rest, we shall  rest. We shall hear the angels, we  shall see the whole sky all diamonds,  we shall see how all earthly evil,  all our sufferings, are drowned in  the mercy that will fill the whole  world. And our life will grow  peaceful, tender, sweet as a caress... (wipes away tears) Poor, dear Uncle Vanya, you are  crying... (through her tears) In your life you haven't known what  joy was; but wait, Uncle Vanya,  wait... We shall rest... (embraces him) We shall rest!

Curtains close. AUDIENCE bursts into applause. As the curtain opens and the players take their bows, we in the audience: Lillian and Ernest, Lillian clapping mad crying, nudging Ernest to clap harder. And in the back stands Harry York.
(to himself) Not bad, Farmer. Not half bad.

A celebration in progress. Masks of Comedy and Tragedy ha on the walls. DRAMA STUDENTS lounge about: eating, drinki talking noisily. Bing Crosby is on the record player, sin "I've Got The World on a String." The Drama Teacher is ho court to a group of attentive students.
Art is a constant struggle. Some of  you have the will but not the ability.  For others, the opposite. I don't  wish to be harsh, but only one of  you on stage tonight combined the  two...
The front door opens. Frances and Chet enter.
On cue.
The young men rush over to congratulate her. Frances take mock bow. She laughs as people cheer. TWO GIRLS observe f the back.
I could really learn to hate her.
Stand in line.
Things have quieted down. The Drama Teacher has cornered  Frances and is gesticulating drunkenly, waving a copy of  "Voice of Action." Frances is also tipsy, but pays close  attention to her mentor.
This is the answer: a subscription  drive to "Voice of Action!" First  prize is a trip to Moscow! You could  visit the art theatre, maybe even  meet Stanislavski!
But I'll never win that.
Yes, yes, it's all arranged.  Everyone's collecting subscriptions  in your name. And the best part is:  the trip returns you to New York.
(intrigued) Really?
New York, Frances! Broadway! This is  your chance! You belong on the stage!
(flattered/embarrassed) Thank you.
A door opens quietly and Harry slips in. He smiles at Fra who disentangles herself from her teacher and rushes over
Hi, Harry. Did you see the play?
You think I'd miss it?
Well? What'd you think?
(shrugs) I just wanted to see how you looked.
How'd I look?
(teasing) Enh.
(smiling) Don't be a rat, Harry.
You looked okay. (glances around) Joint's pretty dead. How 'bout I  take you home?
She hesitates, looks around and sees Chet passed out, sno in a chair. She takes Harry's arm.
The beach is very dark, but the sweep of the lighthouse p up an old Chevrolet parked near the shore.
You really think so?
Frances and Harry are sitting in the back seat.
Honest. When you were up there, you  were really... there, know what I  mean? Everyone else looked stupid.
I don't know... I did... feel  different... Alive.
Yeah, it's a gift. You gotta do  something with it.
Yeah, but if I win this trip, Mama'll  kill me. She hates Russians. I do  want to go, though... to New York,  especially... but I wanted to do  it...
What?
Quietly.
You're not the quiet type, Frances.
They are silent for a while.

You know, my old man was an inventor.  Spent his whole life down in the  basement trying to design  transcontinental underground  railroads, stuff like that. Well, I  was supposed to be his partner. When  I told him the smell of his workshop  made me sick, I thought he was going  to die right there.
What happened to him?
He retired to Florida... made a  killing in vending machines.
He grins ironically and Frances laughs.
I kick myself sometimes, but the  thing is, I would have been miserable  living his life.
...So you think I should go.
Sure. Try this acting thing. You can  make good money at it.
I don't know, Harry. I... I want so  many...
You don't know what you want.
Yeah.
She looks at him, smiles wistfully.
Not in the long run, anyway.
She starts to unbutton her blouse. Harry is pleasantly  surprised, but unnerved.
Frances...
What?
Well... don't you think it's up to  me to...
Come on, Harry. This is America,  land of the free. (whispers) I thought we might go skinny dipping. (pregnant pause...  smile...) For starters.
Harry can't believe his good fortune.
Lillian's face, distorted.
Communists?! No daughter of mine is  going to Communist Russia!
Lillian is in her apron, canning peaches.
You act like I'm a bomb-thrower,  Mama. It's just a trip.
She leaves. Lillian follows her down the narrow -- almost institutional -- hallway.
But they're using you!
Oh Ma, they're not using me. It's  just a chance to travel, see things.  Besides, it's the only way I can get  to New York.
They've reached Frances' room. She puts on her coat.
I'll pay your way to New York. I'll  work, I'll slave. I'll sell my  vegetables to the truck farmers, or --
(sighs) Oh, Mama, don't you understand?
She stares out the window. We see Ernest mowing the lawn.
I have to do this on my own. You  see, I've learned your lesson very  well. To do what I think is right  and everyone else be damned.
Frances turns and heads back down the hall. Lillian follo
I never taught you that!
Frances keeps walking.
Little sister, if you don't wise up  soon, it's going to be out of my  hands!
They've reached the kitchen. Ernest is there, sweating,  drinking water.
It isn't in your hands, Mama. It's  my life.
Yes, but important people are  concerned about this. Judge Hillier  spoke to Alma Styles --
I don't care.
(grimacing) ...You will.
She storms outside. Frances sighs, looks at her father.
What do I do, Dad?
You really want to go?
Of course.
And you think it's worth all this?
If I didn't, I wouldn't put you  through it.
...Then go.
Lillian has a few reporters drawn off to one side. Alma S and a MINISTER stand nearby. A CROWD has gathered. Inside the station, more reporters are milling around Frances.

(almost conspiratorial) The authorities tell me there's no  legal way I can stop her, but the  way I see it, it's bigger than me or  my family... (the following is  heard faintly as  b.g. to the scene  below) American integrity, that's what's at  stake here. They're sending my  daughter to the heartland of darkness.  . .the dark forces that would  overthrow our country. Your country.  My country.
Ernest and the Drama Teacher stand at Frances' side.
Has your earlier denial of God led  you to Communism?
I'm not a Communist.
But Frances, you said --
I said all countries are of cultural  interest. Besides, Russia has the  greatest theatre company in the world.
Better than any American company?
What do you think of Stalin?
Not much. Ask me about Stanislavski.
Who?
(suddenly frantic,  loud) Help me save my daughter! Save the  children of America.
A TALL SPECTRAL MAN dressed in black adds:
Repent, Frances, Repent!
Repent! Repent!
Their cries seem weird, almost deranged, and Lillian is t aback.
Passengers climb onto the bus. As Frances is hugged by he Drama Teacher, the Tall Spectral Man approaches her. In h arms he carries a potted plant, a Bible, and a flashlight

Bless you, sister, bless you. (dignified, as though  conducting some  bizarre ceremony) Here is a Bible for solace... and  this plant to remind you of the  eternal seed in all of us... and  finally, a flashlight to illuminate  your path through darkest Russia.

Frances accepts the gifts, bewildered. The Tall Spectral stares at her through hollow eyes. She staggers on toward the bus, looking like a bedraggled Statue of Liberty. The Tall Spectral Man sings an ethereal hymn. Lillian blocks Frances' path. Frances looks at her tearfu
I love you, Mama. (turns to her father) I love you, Dad.
(hugging her) Be careful, Francie.
As Frances climbs on board.
Frances, I'm warning you. I'm gonna  throw myself beneath the wheels.  I'll do it, Frances. Frances!

Inside the bus, Frances stares out the window and shakes head sadly. The bus starts. Everyone looks at Lillian. She is  motionless... Furious. Frances sighs, and the bus moves o unimpeded. There is a homicidal rage in Lillian's eyes as she stares after the vehicle. Then the Reporters rush toward her.
What do you say now, Mrs. Farmer?
She looks down, her lip quivering. Humiliated, crumbling. As the reporters shout unanswered questions, Ernest puts arm around his wife and leads her away.
Lillian is happily thumbing through her scrapbook. Her ha runs down the page, and we SEE a series of headlines, wit photos: MOTHER UNABLE TO HALT GIRL'S TRIP TO RUSSIA (Photo Lillian & Frances)
Then: MOTHER WARNS AGAINST REDS IN SCHOOLS (Photo Lillian)

Next is a SNAPSHOT of Frances on board on ocean liner. Then TWO SNAPSHOTS of her in what is clearly Moscow. She  wears a Russian hat. The Kremlin stands behind her. Then SNAPSHOTS of her in New York, with a small clipping  from the "New York Times": Visits Moscow Art Theatre...

head_text.subj: YOUNG ACTRESS RETURNS FROM RUSSIA, ASPIRES TO THE BROADWA

text: Below this is a magazine advertisement showing Frances in glossy Chesterfield ad. Her hair is swept up off her head and she looks glamorous, artificial, very different from we've seen her. Lillian takes up the paste brush and liberally swabs the  opposite -- blank -- page of her scrapbook. A handwritten letter from Frances lies beside her. She removes a clippi from the letter and spreads it out. The clipping says: "S OF TOMORROW" and shows a semi-circle of girl's faces insi garish stars. Lillian circles Frances' photo and sits back to admire it
We SEE the Hollywood sign in the distance... then CHANGE  FOCUS to see the front of the studio...

Frances' hair is tightly curled. She is dressed in a  grotesquely ruffled white gown and seated on a small stoo Behind her TWO ASSISTANTS fuss with bunches of white  carnations hanging on a grid. A seasoned PUBLICIST kneels nearby and a woman with a coffee cup, CLAIRE, surveys the scene.
One more time.
Frances stares dramatically off into space.
Hobbies?
The camera clicks.
Oh, I swim some... play the piano  badly... and I read like a fiend: I  like history.

No, no, people don't want that. Now  listen: you spend lots of time at  the beach. You're crazy about dancing.  And you're the kind of girl who's  just a little in love with love. Get  it? Now try again? Hobbies?
Look, I...
(writing in notepad) Beach... dancing... in love with  love.
(ironically) That's me.
The camera clicks again. MR. BEBE -- a tall, brooding, we dressed man -- ENTERS.
Good morning, Mr. Bebe!
Who's this?
Frances Farmer, contract player, six- month option.
(an assessment) Okay. Good tits. Can't we show them  off a little more?
I guess so, sir.
(nods, stares again  at Frances) Very fine bone structure.
He leaves. Claire stares after him with profound contempt

(coming up to Claire) Not much to work with. How's this: (reading) 'The most interesting thing about  Frances Farmer is that her road to  Hollywood was 12,000 miles long.  After winning a beauty contest, the  first prize of which was a trip to  Europe...' She made some deal with  the Commies and went to Moscow, but  I'm not going to say that, am I?
Heavens no. Go on.
Um... 'Miss Farmer returned to New  York City and had a brief fling with  the Broadway stage before coming  west to seek stardom.'
'Brief fling?'
Well, actually she couldn't get hired,  but lucky for her, some guy in our  New York office saw her. She says  soon as she gets a stake, she's going  back.
Claire rolls her eyes. She's heard this before. The Camera clicks again. Frances is frozen in time.

TWO STUDENTS are doing a scene from "Design For Living."  Others sit around watching, whispering, flirting, sleepin but Frances is paying very close attention, making notes. The MAN next to her rubs her arm and whispers something. grimaces and pays no attention. Then she notices, two row in front, a young handsome student, DICK, who's also maki notes. She stares at him for a second, then back at the s
A tiny rustic cottage, dogs everywhere. Two identical old Fords are parked out front.
Frances sits on the couch talking on the phone.
Did you get the check?... Oh my God,  it opened?!, what'd you think?
Water lands on her face. She grimaces playfully.
Well, I hope I get bigger parts,  they don't come much smaller.
The last line is garbled as water streams in her mouth. S fumbles for something on the floor.
No, I'm fine. I just have water in  my mouth.
She finds a water pistol on the floor, picks up the phone and starts searching for her assailant.
No, Mama, I'm not changing my name.  They can't actually make you, you  know? Most people don't realize that. (playfully, covering  receiver) Oh Dick...
She flings open the bathroom door and finds him: Dick fro drama class. A furious water battle ensues.
No, no, nothing's going on. (fast) I love you too, Mama. Give my love  to Dad. Bye!
She hangs up, lowers her gun as Dick squirts her. She's  getting wet. Her shirt clinging to her breasts. She likes it.
Okay, handsome. You win.
On the small screen we SEE Frances in the arms of a MAN I FIRE CHIEF'S HAT.
Kurt!
Oh, Angela! Go with these trappers!  They'll lead you safely down the  mountain...
But, Kurt, I...
No, No arguments. Be my good girl  and go. There's a forest, a burning  forest, and you know what I have to  do!
Oh, Kurt!
Oh Angela, my own... Angela!

ON SCREEN the corners of Frances' mouth begin to tremble, but her eyes remain wide and innocent. The Fire Chief slo inclines his head toward hers. The brim of his hat hits h forehead. Frances covers her face with her hands and burs out laughing. The Fire Chief looks stunned. She tries to  control herself.
I'm sorry... (looking into camera) I'm sorry, let's go back.
Laughter inside the screening room. A small light flicks and from behind we dimly SEE TWO MEN.
(irate) What the hell is that? What's she  doing?
That's talent, Andy.
(after a beat) Oh.

Frances smiles and eases shut the screening room door. We HEAR the Laughing Man inside shout: "Let's see that again Frances puts a cigarette in her mouth and fishes for a ma A man's hand appears, holding a lighter. She looks up: It Harry, wearing a garish Hawaiian shirt and a Panama hat.
Harry! Harry-god-damn-York! A real  person!
Frances throws her arms around him. They hug warmly.
How ya doin', Farmer?
Me? Look at you! What're you doing  in Hollywood?
Came to get a tan.
They compare forearms.
Not bad. But come on, Harry; what's  the real reason?
(staring out) Kaminski.
Yeah, I read about that. Terrible  business, suicide.
Since when do you believe the papers?  They killed him, kid.
What?
They killed him. They threw him out  that window.
Oh no...
Eight stories.
She stares down two stories to the ground, imagining:
Jesus.
(also staring down) Yup. Poor bastard lay there on the  sidewalk and he couldn't die. Too  god damn much heart. He just didn't  want to die.
(walking on) But... but why, Harry...? Why'd they  do it?

(shrugs) He wouldn't play ball. What can I  tell ya... it's done. (brightening) Anyway, I didn't want to be next, so  I skipped town; came down here to  work for some big-wig. Tail and nail  job. (confidentially) I'm sort of a non-gentleman's non- gentleman. (turns around,  displaying his shirt) How d'ya like the camouflage?
You jackass! (pushing him down the  stairs) C'mon, let's get out of here.
Harry and Frances walking arm in arm.
Not bad. It was slow at first, but  I'm doing bits now.
I always told ya, Frances. You got  real ability.
(smiling) I know what ability you're interested  in.
Hey, I'm a man, aren't I? Whattaya  say we have dinner, then maybe head  out to the beach, rub some of this  tan off each other. (off her sober  expression) For old time's sake.
(serious) Harry... I met someone.
(stiffens slightly) Yeah? What is he -- muscleman?  Lifeguard?
Frances shakes her head.
Actor?
She nods.
Good. Then it's temporary. (whispers) All actors are phonies.
He's joking, but she doesn't respond.
Serious, huh?
Yeah.
Hey that's great, Farmer, just great.
She smiles wistfully, seeing him cover up his disappointm She squeezes his arm and they continue walking.

Lights being adjusted, cameras set, actors walking throug their blocking. In the midst of this we SEE Frances, dres in western attire, making a point to the WARDROBE MISTRES who is listening without enthusiasm.
(spreading her arms) These creases... I look like I just  came from the laundry! I'm supposed  to be hiding out in boxcars, sleeping  on floors.
(cool) This is the suit we fitted on you,  Miss Farmer.
(friendly) Oh, I know that. But it could look  more realistic, don't you think?
(looking her over) It'll do. No one will notice.
I'll notice.
We HEAR a man conspicuously clearing his throat. Both wom turn as Mr. Bebe steps forward.
Oh, Mr. Bebe, good morning.
He nods imperceptibly.
Come along with me, Fanny.
She hesitates, then goes.
That's Frances. I'm not the cookbook.
(leading her off) You see: We've got to change that  name.
Frances and Bebe come through the sound stage door into t light. He gestures to indicate what direction they're goi but remains silent, watching her. She's uncomfortable,  blinking like a bird.
I like your looks. You have the  classical bone structure of the very  great beauties... Garbo, Dietrich --
Thank you --
I intend to make a great deal of  money off you.
Frances is taken aback. This is all rather blunt.
Since we have you on a seven year  contract, I'm planning long-range.  I'm going to loan you out to Sam  Goldwyn to make a picture called  "Come and Get It."
Really? That's a very good book.  It'd make a terrific --
Never mind that. I'm concerned about  you. Your attitude.
They hear a ruckus in the distance and turn and look:  PICKETERS are fighting with POLICE. It is raucous, brutal Bebe turns back to her with a stern look:

Society is falling apart, Miss Farmer,  and people have to buckle down, do  their jobs. You see, I view myself  as the Henry Ford of motion picture  industry, and I can't have the fellow  who puts on the wheels arguing with  the man who installs head-lights,  now can I?
But I'm concerned with everything,  Mr. Bebe.
(fierce but very muted) No, I'm concerned with everything.
But I'm the one up there on the  screen.
That's right. You're an actress,  Miss Farmer and your job is to act.
She's about to reply, but he quickly takes her hand and r it to his lips. Kisses it very formally, like a suitor. T turns and walks into the sumptuous executive office build She watches him go.
Brightly colored bulbs flashing, causing the wisps of fog around them to glow. The bulbs spell:

head_text.speaker/title: "COME AND GET IT" WITH SEATTLE'S OWN FRANCES FARMER

text: A noisy CROWD is gathered outside the theatre, straining  against velvet cordons. Big black limos disgorge couples formal evening wear, to the applause of the crowd. All  slightly small-town, off-key. Harry, now sporting a mustache, hat pulled down over his  face, stands across the street.
(puffing his cigarette) Not bad, Farmer.
Two limousines streaking through the night.
Frances sits next to a faceless STUDIO EXECUTIVE. She's a dolled up. She looks uncomfortable. Silence. She glances at the limo ahead of them.
Dick sits between Lillian and Ernest A REPORTER and  PHOTOGRAPHER crouch in front of them.
I guess it's no secret that I'm proud.  Only twenty-one years old, and look  at all she's done. (confidentially) As for her looks, I flatter myself  that she gets them from me.
Obviously.
He winks at the reporters.
And not only has Frances come home a  star; she's also brought me this big  handsome lug of a son-in-law!
Mr. Farmer, what was your reaction  when Frances told you she had  married...
Dwayne. Dwayne Steele.
What...? Oh. Well, I was pleased, of  course. Richard... uh, Dwayne, is a  real gentleman.
Dick smiles and hugs them both.
Well, all I can say is: I feel like  I've known these two for years!
(girlishly) Oh, Dwayne! (overcome) This is like a fairy tale!
They're stopped at a light. Outside their window we SEE  DERELICTS, casualties of the depression, huddled in the n
She's staring at the derelicts. We feel her sympathy for  them. Almost like she'd rather be out there. A MAN WITH H EYES shouts something at them.
What'd he say?
She rolls down her window. The Studio Executive beside he looks at her like she's crazy.
(to Driver) Let's go. We'll be late.
The limousine lurches forward. Frances settles back in he seat, letting the night air sweep over her face.

The two limos pull up, the second emptying first. As Fran gets out, the CROWD cheers wildly. She walks past them, e glazed. She doesn't see Harry, who is held back by cordon Lillian is posing and signing autographs. In her tight, f dress, Frances looks radiant but constricted. As she walk voices assault her:
There she is!
How does it feel to be back in  Seattle, Frances?
A little strange.
Isn't she gorgeous?
This way.
How's the movie, Frances?
It's okay.
Smile, little sister, smile.
Frances sees her mother smiling nervously. They have ente the:
Again there is a cordoned area in the center where Seattl luminaries are sipping champagne. Reporter #1 lurches for
Can you make some statement about  Seattle, how the city helped you, or  the schools --
Well, the truth is the city had  nothing to do with it. I was lucky.  And what wasn't luck was hard work.
(disappointed) Oh.
Judge Hillier's Wife, whom we recognize as the Woman who  shouted at Frances in the auditorium, steps forward in a  garish gown. She's holding a large key.
Miss Farmer, I can't tell you how  proud I am to meet you.

She embraces and kisses Frances, who's more than a little put off. After the kiss, she takes firm hold of Frances'  hand and won't let go. Judge Hillier steps to his wife's  side. Lillian also approaches.
On behalf of the Seattle Ladies Club,  as a token of our vast admiration --
Excuse me.
(startled) Yes...?
Don't I know you?
I don't believe so.
Sure. You shouted at me in the  auditorium when I read my essay.
No, my dear. You must be mistaken.
(barely audible) Oh bullshit.
I beg your pardon?
(to the dignitaries) Listen, I'm still the same girl that  wrote that essay, the same girl who  went to Russia, and you people aren't  proud to meet me at all.

A hideous silence. Judge Hillier is fuming. His wife is  aghast, the key to the city extended awkwardly in front o her. She shoves it into Frances' arms. Frances moves to leave, but her arm is taken by the Studi Executive, who escorts her into the theatre. The crowd  follows. Lillian is utterly mortified.

We TRACK along the side of the theatre. An exit door is t open, and Frances storms out. As she does, she trips over OLD INDIAN BEGGAR. She stops and looks at him. He peers u at her with large forlorn eyes... then holds out his hand connection is made. All the anger drains out of her. She  gives him money, several bills. He breaks into a wonderfu crooked grin. She starts away, hesitates, then hands him key to the city. He stares at it, bewildered. She strides away toward her limousine, which is now parke with several others at the end of the alley. The CHAUFFEU are talking and smoking a cigarette. Her chauffeur sees h and hurries to his limo. As it pulls into the street, we Harry drift back to the curb and stare after it.
Frances sits on the old wood jetty staring out at the wat the lighthouse... Harry approaches.
...It's one thing to marry the guy,  but did you have to sleep with him?
She cracks up. Harry laughs at his mistake.
Shit. I meant the other way around.
(still laughing) Well, the studio told me not to.
Is that why you did it?
Who ever thought they'd be right for  once? Jesus, Harry... it's a zoo  back there --
You're telling me.
Dick... and my mother! She acts like  she's on Mars or something --
Well, she's back to earth now. They're  all pretty huffed up about your  leaving. I think you better go back,  kid.
Forget it.
He looks at her thoughtfully, then sits.

You know, the funny thing is: it's  not a great movie. I mean it could've  been, but they screwed it up, gave  it a happy ending. And all my friends,  I know they're going to smile and  say they loved it.
If they say they love it, they'll  probably love it. Not everybody lies,  you know?
(warmly, to him) No, they don't, do they?
Beat.
Frances, you're a movie star now. If  you give them what they want, you  can get anything.
I don't have what they want, Harry. (stares at the water) Harry, will you tell me something?  How can I keep making movies when  people in the streets are starving?
Some people starve, kid. Until we  can do something about it, they might  as well see a movie. Makes 'em feel  better.
But I don't want to be like that. I  want to do something... (important)
What're you gonna do, waste your  talent? Why not use it to make  something worthwhile. You can do  that, you know?
(laughs) Yeah, if I don't make too big an ass  of myself.
They start to walk now along the beach. We see Harry's ca and the chauffeured limousine parked above.
Tell you what. Let's ditch the limo.  Let me drive you up to that red carpet  in my beat up Chevy.
The hell you will, Harry York.
Come on, Cinderella, your pumpkin  awaits.
She shakes her head mischievously... moves backward  unbuttoning her coat.
(like a clock striking) Bong... bong... bong...
The coat falls.
Don't start, Farmer.
(dropping her scarf) It's midnight, Harry. My glittering  raiments are dissolving.
(nervously) The chauffeur. He's watching.
He deserves a show. He missed the  movie.
I'm serious, Frances. This is  important.
(kicking off a shoe) I know.
She kicks off another shoe, sailing it into the water. Frances is zipping off her dress. Harry bends to pick up the first shoe.
A single glass slipper left glittering  on the pearly sands. Who was that  girl, anyway?
Harry watches her, mesmerized. The dress is off.
'Come and get it,' Harry.
She skips off down the beach, her dress strewn on the san After a moment, from the darkness, we SEE her underclothe fly into view. Harry can restrain himself no longer.
(excited) Hot damn!
He drops the shoe and runs after her, tearing off his clo After a moment, from the darkness, we hear her squeals of laughter.
The street outside the Studio Main Gate. Actors, director etc. arrive in their shiny expensive autos. Among them is Frances in her old battered Ford. She waves to the Guard drives through.
As Frances pulls into her parking space, Claire, the woma from the photo session, strolls up.
Hi Frances, got a minute?
Sure, Claire. If you don't mind  walking my way.
They walk toward the dressing room.
(nervous) Well, I suppose I should just say  it. It's your clothes.
(bewildered) My clothes?
Yeah, I mean slacks... and work  clothes... and that awful car --
It's a perfectly good car. It runs.
Yes, but... Really, I hate to sound...  it's just that the public expects  something different from its stars.  People won't take you seriously.
I don't care if my clothes are taken  seriously. Or my car.
You know what I mean.
Uh-huh. You mean what if the public  finds out I perspire? And wear slacks.  And drive an old jalopy? What if  they find out I'm a real person. Oh  no! Say it ain't so! Not a real  person!
Claire is laughing. They go inside.
Posh, fit for a star. Frances smiles at the MAKEUP MAN.
Morning, Eddie.
As Frances sits at the table and Eddie goes to work:
That's not all, Frances. Mr. Bebe is  very concerned about your politics.  He hears you've been donating money,  speaking at rallies.
Yup. Claire... please, please tell  Mr. Bebe that if he worried half as  much about his scripts as he does  about my private life, we'd make a  lot better movies.
I'm sorry, Frances. It's my job, you  know?
I know. (imitating Bebe) 'This is a factory and we each have  our jobs. The writer writes, the  director directs, and the actress...'
(laughing) ...acts. I'll relay your message.
Dick is talking on the phone in the living room.
Yes, of course she'll make a statement  on women's rights. Call back tomorrow,  okay?
He hangs up. Immediately the phone rings again. He stares it wearily, then answers:
(pointedly) Dwayne Steele's residence.
Through the half-open door to the bedroom we see Frances  dozing, an open script laid out beside her.
Yes. (confused) What...? (hurt) Yes. Yes, I'll tell her.
He hangs up. Stares off. Slowly enters the bedroom. Frances looks up.
You learn your lines?
(nods drowsily) Sort of.
There've been some calls.
Who?
Well... about half an hour ago that  woman from the talent department  called, what's her name?
Claire?
Yeah, Claire. She said she was fired.  Too bad, huh?
(apprehensively) Fired?
Yeah. She said she delivered your  message and that you'd understand.
Frances looks stricken. Dick presses on.
There was another call too. From  your agent. He says your summer stock  deal is all set. So you're going  back east, huh?
...Yes.
Without me.
(sighing) Showdown.
You weren't going to tell me, were  you? Just pack up and leave, is that  it?
Dick, we need some time apart --
Hey, I'm not a complete fool, you  know. I can see you're going sour on  me, and when I try to do something  about it, you turn your back and say  it's nothing.
Dick, I can't even breathe here...
Dwayne! I'm Dwayne now! And you damn  well better get used to it!
(softly, remembering) Dick...

I don't suppose it occurred to you  that I might want to leave too, that  I might want to do theatre? No, 'cause  you don't want me along, do you? And  the reason has nothing to do with  summer stock.
No?
No. It's all about that night, isn't  it?
(bewildered) What night?
The premiere. I never pressed you  about it but god damn it, you're  gonna tell me right here and right  now what happened and where the hell  you were!
(quietly) You want his name?
Dick is crumbling inside.
What...?
We watch it sink in. Confusion... self-pity... building  gradually to resentment and rage. He starts to throw a  tantrum. Hurling things around the room. Frances just sits there.
My God... I think you're overplaying  this a bit...?
He hurls a pillow against the wall and rushes out. Frances looks after him, then turns. She's now facing the bureau.
Goodbye, Dick.
A mirror sits on top of the bureau. She looks into it. Do like her expression. Turns the mirror away.

A playbill in a theatre lobby reads: "Mt. Kisco Playhouse 1937 Summer Season: 'THE PETRIFIED FOREST'." Among the na listed is: "Frances Farmer, the 'Come And Get It' Girl.  Suddenly we HEAR an eruption of applause.

TIGHT SHOT on two men: HAROLD CLURMAN -- a thoughtful  aristocratic man -- and CLIFFORD ODETS, who is taller,  slimmer, with black hair and intense dark eyes. Around th we see (mostly HEAR) the AUDIENCE going crazy, leaping to its feet, yelling "Bravo! Bravo!" Clurman and Odets sit  impassively. As the hurrahs die down and the audience fil out, the two men sit there. Finally Clurman turns to Odet Odets nods very slightly.
Frances sits in the cramped room, listening intently to  Clurman. Occasionally she sneaks a glance at Odets, who i pacing like some caged beast.

The Group is more than a theatre  company. It's the embodiment of an  ideal. Our approach allows the actor  to be an artist in the fullest sense,  a creative individual and an  instrument of change. You see --
(watching Odets) Really, Mr. Clurman, you don't have  to sell me.

Forgive my indulgence. Seems we always  lecture those who are on time for  those who are tardy. The point is,  Mr. Odets here has written a wonderful  play. Most of the roles are cast,  but we haven't found our female  lead...
Who is she?
She's a tramp from Newark.
Forgive me, but I think you'd be  perfect for the part.
Odets is pacing furiously, seizing their attention. He st looks at her, then resumes.

Miss Farmer, for me this is not a  play: it's an assault... a  seduction... a plea for understanding.  I think we live in a time when new  art works should shoot bullets...  and you make very attractive  ammunition.
He stops. Tentatively, almost boyishly, he smiles. She returns it. She's charmed.
And what's the title of this seduc...  assault?
(mysterious, intimate) 'Golden Boy.'

It reads "Golden Boy". Crowds of people streaming out of lobby. A sign over the box office reads: "Tomorrow's  performances sold out." Odets sits on the curb. Behind him the lights in the thea lobby flicker off. PEDESTRIANS stroll by: an odd mix of  affluent theatre crowd and 1930s bums. Frances emerges from the theatre, sees him sitting there. Sits beside him.
Hi.
He nods.
You wanted to talk?
Another nod. He's silent. He peers up the street. A GIRL, 16, selling pencils catches his eye.
You see that girl?
She looks like a waif: tough, vulnerable, pleading with a WEALTHY COUPLE, following them down the street. A drama b played out in the distance, out of earshot.
That's who my play is about.
Frances watches the girl.
That's me, Clifford.
(strong) I know, but I'm not seeing it. It's  there, Frances, the fire is there,  but it's not coming through. You're  lazy --
The same conversation continuing:
I'm not!
Yes, you win them, you bring them  into your heart, touch them, but you  don't set them on fire!
But I want to. I'm trying!
I need an incendiary! An arsonist!
Then show me! That's what I'm here  for, to learn, to grow!
Good. Then it's very simple. You  have to stop being afraid, Frances.  It's in you.
Clurman is delivering a speech in the background as  PHOTOGRAPHERS snap pictures. Behind them on the platform  Frances and Odets continue their conversation in whispers
I can see it. You just have to let  it out. Trust it. No one will quash  you here, but it's still a fight, a  struggle! Being true to your art,  being honest, is always a struggle!
We now HEAR Clurman's speech. The initial words below wer background to the above. What we HEAR now is underlined:

...Not only an artist, but an  instrument of change. We must look  to the world around us, not content  to observe, but to take an active  hand in redressing its wrongs. We  will not stand idly by as Fascist  bombs obliterate democracy. We  contribute our profits, for if fascism  is not stopped in Spain, it will  spread across Europe, jeopardizing  the struggle of civilized man to  survive. (presenting check to
The artist, to be vital, must be a  soldier too.
I'm not afraid of struggle, Clifford.
Yes you are. We all are. The first  step is to acknowledge our fear.
They're walking. The conversation continues.
Face it! Confess it! You're weak!
I'm not!
You're afraid!
I'm not!
You don't want to show your whole  soul -- ugly, mis-shapen, and pitiful --  you don't want to show it --
(angry) God damn it, Clifford, will you shut  up! I tell you, I want to give these  things! I want to give them to the  audience, and I can give them, I  will give them, so shut up!
She is seething. Gorgeous. Alive. He smiles, watching her.
Good, good. Give them that.
What?

As she feels the anger coursing through her body she real what he's talking about. She looks at him, still breathin heavily. Gradually her face turns toward a smile. He reaches out and, with exquisite tenderness, kisses her
Later. They enter slightly drunk, laughing. He takes her  coat.
Madam...?
Thank you.
She's looking at the apartment. He sees her. A dark thoug flickers across his face, and he breaks into an exaggerat act:
Oh my God! Frances, I'm such a cad.  I can't go through with this. My  wife is in Europe, but this is her  house... (gesturing off) her bedroom. I can't ask you to...
(playing along) Oh well. I guess I better leave then.
She starts to put on her coat. He watches her.
Okay, but come here first.
Huh.
(Leading her down  hall) Come here. I want to show you  something.
He opens the bedroom door.
The bed is drawn back, and the sheets are sprinkled with  rose petals. Frances' eyes are large. The kiss is very hungry now.

Bebe's huge desk. Variety Headline: "ACTRESS FIGHTS FASCI Next to the newspaper are a dozen pencils which Bebe is l up precisely parallel. His expression is totally obsessiv crazed. Behind him a woman (TORA) is cutting his hair. A STUDIO L paces nearby.
And on top of her political  activities, now she's got a lawyer.  She wants out of her contract, Mr.  Bebe. She says she's through with  motion pictures.
(muttering) I'm sure it wasn't me, it wasn't  me...
Excuse me, sir?
I don't know who she fucked to get  where she is, but I don't think it  was me.
Tora is massaging the back of Bebe's neck. He's oblivious
(startled) Well... you could always dump her,  Mr. Bebe. Teach her a lesson. There  are a million beautiful girls out  there who don't give a damn about  politics.

That's not the point. Frances Farmer  has the world by the tit because of  this studio, and now she thinks she  can waltz off without a thank you.  No. No, that young lady has a  contract, and she's going to honor  it.
Oh. I mean, good.
I think it's time to take the gloves  off. (scowls, speaks into  intercom) Get me some reporters. (afterthought) Particularly Louella Parsons!
During this conversation, Bebe has been drawing on the  Variety. We now see his work. Beneath the headline was a  photo of Frances, on whom Bebe has drawn a mustache.
The marquee for "Golden Boy" reads "Held Over". USHERS ar opening the glass doors from the empty lobby onto the str We HEAR thunderous applause from the inside.

Frances emerges from the stage door to a throng of AUTOGR SEEKERS. She smiles tiredly, but good-naturedly complies. little ways back stands a boyish YOUNG MAN holding a sing red carnation. When the Autograph-seekers are satisfied a all but a few have trailed away, the Young Man steps forw
Miss Farmer... I've never done this  before... but... I had to tell ya'  you're great!
He shyly hands her the flower.
Thank you very much. I'm glad you  liked the play.
She smiles and begins to walk away. The Young Man follows her.
I'm really sad it's closing. Now  what am I gonna do on Tuesday nights?
You can always come see it in London.
Only if you were in it. Are you?
I wouldn't miss it.
Boy, I'd love to... but I'm going to  Hollywood.
(smiling) Are you an actor?
Hell yes!... well, okay, I'm still  in school. But as soon as I  graduate... California, here I come!
(after a pause) Are you really serious? About acting?
Why... yes.
Then don't go to Hollywood.
Why?
I'm telling you straight, if you  have any serious ambitions, stay  clear of the place. It'll crush you.
You sound as if you hate it.
No, I don't hate it.
Again she walks on. He follows.
Aren't you ever going back?
...Not if I can help it.
Gosh! You'll break a lot of hearts.
They'll mend.
(after a pause) What about your husband?
Frances stops walking, her eyes shoot to the Young Man's  face.
What?
Will you be getting back together?  When you quit Hollywood, I mean.
What is this?
The Young Man suddenly seems much older, and there is no  sign of the awkward boyishness.
Is it true you're getting a divorce?  Comrade?
Why, you... you little bastard!
The Young Man grins.
Thanks for our chat, Miss Farmer. Be  seeing you.
He begins to walk away.
Just one minute...
(turning) You're wasting your time, lady.  Nothing's off the record with me.
He is gone.
Odets sits at a table in back, drinking and writing in a  notebook. Frances comes up to him. He smiles, draws her to him for a hug.
How'd it go?
She hesitates, still affected by the incident outside the theatre.
'But how do I know you love me?'
Your big speech?

'How do I know it's true? You'll get  to be the champ. They'll all want  you, all the girls! But I don't care.  I've been undersea a long time. When  they'd put their hands on me I used  to say, "This isn't it! This isn't  what I mean!" It's been a mysterious  world for me! But Joe, I think you're  it! I don't know why, I think you're  it. Take me home with you.'
(smiling) I already have.
She nods, turns her back to him.
How's it sound?
The speech? Real good.
You think I got it?
You got it.
Yeah. Yeah, tonight I think I got  it.
She is crying.
Frances comes in the front door with a bag of groceries,  removes her key. Walks into the living room, stops short. Clurman is sitting on the couch, a bottle and two glasses front of him.
Hello, Harold.
(nodding) Frances.
(looking around) Where's Clifford?
He's not here.
Oh.
She sits.
Bourbon?
He pours. She drinks hers, watching him.
What's up?
I hear you're meeting with the studio  lawyers to get out of your contract.
That's right. I don't want them  breathing down my neck while we're  in London.
Well... well, you see, that's the  point. You won't be opening in London.
Frances looks like she's been punched in the stomach.
(insecure) You don't think I'm good enough?
What?! Good Lord no, it's just...  It's money. We needed backing and...  well, we found it.
Who?
An actress.
A rich actress.
Yes. That's the deal. She plays Lorna.

(growing angry) But... but wait a minute. We're  supposed to be different, right?  Clifford says... This theatre is  supposed to be different! And this  play... this play is all about what  greed and money do to people!
I know, but --
(over his line) What does Clifford say?
Right now we have to be practical.
Does Clifford even know? (off his silence) You didn't tell him, did you? (standing) I'm gonna tell him. Where is he?
He knows, Frances.
She collapses back into her seat. Her head is swirling.
(gently) He approved it.
She's glaring at him. He hands her a letter.
I'm very sorry, but... well, Hollywood  wants you back, right?
Her eyes fill with rage. She hurls her drink in his face.
Prick!
He stands and, with as much dignity as he can muster, lea Frances is shaking. She rips open the letter he gave her. Stares at it in horror...
Plain room. A few tables with phones, men on the phones  writing down numbers. Behind them are blackboards with ho names and prices. Off to one side Harry is conferring wit the OWNER.
Of course it can be done, "Mr. Jones,"  but it's how you do it. There's a  way to pay off L.A. cops and a way  to get yourself arrested. First you  gotta know who to approach --
A Man at one of the phones looks up, calls.
You Harry York?
Harry nods, startled. The Man at the table holds up the p and goes to his next call. Harry takes the phone.
Frances on the phone. A half-packed bag lies on the bed. bottle and glass sit beside her. She's been crying and  drinking.
Harry? Harry, where are you?!
Jesus, Frances, how'd you find me?
I called your god-damned office! I  want you to kill him, Harry. You'll  do that for me, won't you? I loved  him, I loved him... that bastard.
Calm down, Frances.
Don't tell me what to do, just give  me his head on a platter!
Frances unfolds the crumpled letter Clurman gave her.
Two lines! Two fucking lines! 'My  wife returns from Europe tomorrow. I  can't see you any more.' Just like  that!
Frances...
(sobbing) Harry, I hate being in love. I don't  ever want to be in love again. I  just hate it!
With the patter of the bookie taking bets beside him, Har listens to Frances' sobs.
I know, Frances... I know.
He HEARS a CLICK on the other end. He hangs up and heaves long slow sigh.
Frances, in a pair of overalls, falls face down into mud.
We SEE the slate: 'Flowing Gold', Scene 31A, Take 11... t the same action is repeated from a slightly different ang Next to her is an old car, its wheels mired in mud.

Slate: Take 12. She falls again, this time splattering mu all over her face and hair. She lies still for a moment,  gritting her teeth. Sitting comfortably in a nearby director's chair is a DIR reading Daily Variety. The headline reads: "STUDIO WINS F WAR ON HOLLYWOOD." Behind the Director, off to one side,  stands Bebe. The A.D. tugs on the Director's sleeve:
How was that?
(looking up) Good, good. One more time.
(standing) For God's sake... why?
Because we want to get it perfect...  just the right combination of fury  and confusion. You can understand  that, can't you, Miss Farmer? We're  serious artists here, right? Right.
The Director glances toward Bebe, who nods with satisfact Frances watches this interaction. She hesitates, then  approaches Bebe. She wipes some mud from her face and dro it at her feet.
Look, Mr. Bebe, you can hold me to  my contract, but you can't break me.  I'm back, and I'm gonna make the  best of it.
(somewhat snidely) I'd like nothing better.
She turns and walks, with an air of pride, to her wardrob trailer.
Lights everywhere. Cars line the driveway. We HEAR the SO of a large party. A car pulls up. BOB BARNES gets out, goes around to open door for Frances. She's exhausted. She doesn't move.
Well... come on.
This is a mistake. No. This is a  disaster.
Come on, it's just what you need!  Let everyone see you. Talk to them,  live it up!
(tiredly) But we've been at it since six this  morning. At least you could've let  me go home and change.
Look, Frances, I didn't want this  job. Think I'm crazy? But you begged  me: improve your image. So please...  lemme try, huh?
(getting out) You're right. I'm sorry. (sighs) Okay, let's go get 'em.
(taking pills from  pocket) Here, take a few of these. Studio  makes 'em in the basement. They keep  the fat off.
(joking) So not only am I a troublesome bitch,  but I'm fat too?
Come on. They make you feel nice and  peppy.
She nods, takes a few. They head for the door.
The DOORBELL CHIMES. The hostess, CONNIE, a pleasant-look woman, answers the door.
Hi! Bob Barnes! Looks like a swell  party!
(pleased) Frances!
As they embrace, Frances looks around with trepidation:
(whisper) God, who's here?
(also whispering) The usual vermin, I'm afraid.
Barnes tries to pull Frances inside. She sees a flurry of waiting faces. Everyone's watching h
(sotto voice) Get me a drink.
Barnes nods, concerned, and crosses to the bar.
Hi everybody.
Some people seem amused, some curious, some scornful. The Director from the mud scene nods to her. Connie is at her side for support. A voice from somewhere pierces the chat
So nice to have you back, Frances.
As Barnes returns with her drink, she turns to Connie:
Connie, can I use the upstairs  bathroom?
Sure.
Later. Frances lies in a bubblebath, relaxing, sipping he drink. She obviously feels a lot better. Someone knocks.
Come in.
A FAT MAN ENTERS, stares at her.
(relaxed) Hi.
He is dumbfounded. He slowly retreats into the hall.
Barnes is talking to a Young Man whom we recognize as the reporter who tricked Frances in New York.
You wouldn't believe the offers!  Just piling in. I mean piling. Some  of the best scripts I've read in  years!
(sarcastic) Yes? My employer will be glad to  hear that.
Louella? Is she here?
How could you miss her?
He nods toward a hard-faced OLDER WOMAN surrounded by  admirers.
Louella's here and I'm talking to  you?
We SEE the open door to the bathroom. Frances, with a tow around her, is going through Connie's closet. Barnes KNOC
Frances? (enters, sees her) Oh no.
Refill my drink, will you, Bob?
(aghast) What're you doing?
Putting on my armor.
Come on, Frances. Louella Parsons is  here. She wants to talk to you, help  you out.
(musing) Louella... didn't she call me a  spoiled little bitch?
Come on, she's an important columnist!  What's the matter? I thought you  wanted these people to forgive you.
(darkly) 'Forgive'...? For What?
I'm sorry... that was an unfortunate  choice of words.
Frances pulls down a dress and inspects it.
You're not kidding. (firmly) Get me a refill, Bob. I'll be down  in a minute.
He nods and retreats out the door.

Everyone chattering away... then hushing slightly. Heads  turn: Frances is descending the stairway in one of Connie dresses. She looks absolutely radiant... like some kind o goddess. Barnes, looking very pleased at her appearance and the ot reaction, hands her the drink.
Thank you.
Then the Young Reporter steps forward.
(his callow youth act) Gee, awful good to see ya again,  Miss Farmer.
Frances bristles. Barnes looks on nervously: It's all bec unravelled again.
My employer would like to know  something very important: is it true  your friend Clifford sleeps in the  nude?
Frances is broiling. She stares at him. Under her steady  gaze, the snide smile gradually fades from his face.
You seem like an intelligent young  man.
Huh?
Can't you find a more dignified way  to make a living?
He blanches. This hits home. Frances turns on her heel an leaves.

Frances rushes out, followed by Barnes and a few curious  partygoers. She is very upset. Tight. Holding it in. Barn pleads with her, tries to stop her, but she leaps in the and speeds off, spewing gravel over him. The partygoers s her with their drinks.

In the pale moonlight we SEE the dim outline of a poster  tacked to the outside wall. The highway disappears down t the sea glittering dully in the distance. We HEAR the RIS SOUND of an approaching car. Its headlights crest the hil illuminating the poster, showing a woman driving an open  car, seated beside the outline of a familiar mustached fi The poster reads, "When You're Riding Alone, You're Ridin with Hitler." The lights grow brighter, almost blinding. car, accelerating furiously, flashes by. Then we HEAR a  motorcycle start up. It emerges from the blackness and sp off in pursuit. A roadsign reads: "Dimout Zone." Frances drives fast, tears running her face. The MOTORCYCLE COP pulls up alongside and shouts, "Pull o She hesitates. He waves insistently. Gradually she slows. gets off his bike and walks over, preparing the usual lec
Okay...
He leans over the car and sees Frances, her hair wild and tangled.
(a come-on) Hey, where's the fire, sister?
(sarcastic) In my eyes, officer.
Cool off, beautiful. Didn't you see  the sign says "Dimout Zone?" (switching off her  lights) There's a war on, you know?
Come on. You're seriously trying to  tell me the Japs can't find Los  Angeles without my headlights?
(testy) I didn't make the law, lady. I just  enforce it.
She switches her headlights back on.
God, you bore me.
She starts the car. The Cop, angry now, lunges in and gra the keys.
Don't touch me!
She leaps out of the car. The Cop turns off the car light As Frances passes his motorcycle, she switches on its lig
Hey!

He runs after her, turning off the motorcycle lights on t way. When he catches her, he grabs her arm. She struggles grabs the flashlight from his belt. She switches it on an holds it high, its beam spearing wildly out to sea. He lu for it, knocks her down. They struggle. He rolls on top o her, pinning both her arms with one hand... trying to han her. She writhes, knees him in the balls. She crawls away desperately clawing at loose stones. The Cop, angry now,  hurls her down again and manages to get the cuffs on. As  they dig into her wrists, she tries to bite him. The Cop, winded from the battle, yanks her to her feet and drags h kicking and screaming, to his motorcycle. He pulls out hi radio mike.
(panting) Santa Monica, this is motor six-sixty- six. I got a live one here.

CLOSE ON front page of the Los Angeles Times, October 194 The headlines read: "24 Jap Ships Sunk", "Errol Flynn Sex Trial Delayed", "Frances Farmer Arrested on Drunk Driving Charge -- Actress Gets $250 Fine and Six Months Probation CAMERA PULLS BACK to show several newspapers spread out o the balcony of Frances' beach house. As the papers ruffle the wind, a little kitten swipes at them. Frances sits in the sun writing in her diary, the same on we saw at the opening of the film. A man's shoes COME INT VIEW.
Got any ginger beer?
She turns, surprised and pleased to see him.
Take a look.
He walks off into the kitchen. She puts her diary away.
(calling) How the hell do you find me anyway?
Animal magnetism! (she laughs) No ginger beer. What's this red stuff?
What's left of my blood.
Think I'll have a glass.
Help yourself. Everyone else has.
Harry returns, sipping the drink.
Very tasty.
She smiles.
(looking around) Nice joint. Can you afford it?
Nope. The studio pays. Thank you,  Harry.
What for?
For not chopping off his head and  serving it to me on a platter.
Well, I would have, you know? I just  didn't know how to cook it.
She laughs.
Six months' probation...? You gotta  learn when to do battle, Farmer.  You're not going to win many bouts  with 200 pound cops.
I took the early rounds.
(laughs) I'll bet.
I don't know. It hurts, Harry. Some  things, no matter what you do with  them, they just hurt.
So you drink, and you fight with a  cop...?

Yeah, and you look at people and you  wonder who the hell they are, what's  going on inside their heads. Sometimes  you can hear it, like a buzzing, the  things that happen in their heads.  And you wonder: does anybody ever  love anybody, really?
Beats me.
Beat.
I gotta get outta here. I gotta get  out of this town.
We see a thought come to him.
Hey look, I got some business down  in San Diego. Whattaya say you come  with me, stay a few days?
No, Harry, I can't -- (right now)
You're coming.
Waterfront bar, full of SAILORS, WHORES, and HEAVY DRINKE Hanging over the bar is San Diego paraphernalia. Frances and Harry sit at a table. Heavy boozing has led t philosophizing:
You know... when I started acting,  you know what I wanted?
He grunts: what?
I just wanted to be part of  something... one thing, one play or  one movie, something that was really  fine... memorable. And I could say:  I did that, I made something good.
And?

Well... to get a crack at something  good, you gotta earn it, you gotta  climb the ladder first. So you do,  you work hard, and all these people  behind you are pushing you up,  shouting you on. And then one day  you realize you are, you're at the  top... and there's nothing there.  And you look behind you and there's  no one below. You're just left there  all alone... swaying in the god-damned  breeze.
In the background, we SEE a DRUNKEN SAILOR lurching towar their table.
Well, like the man said: "You can  make a fresh start with your last  breath."
The Sailor trips and falls across their table, spilling b on Frances and knocking things over.
(irritated) Hey, watch it.
(eyeing her  suggestively) Watch what?
Get away from me, you foul slime.
That's no way for a lady to talk.
Take a walk, pal.
Who said I was a lady?
Sorry I insulted you... bitch.
Hey!
Ahhh, go eat a toilet seat.

The Sailor goes berserk, takes a swing at Frances. Harry  leaps in to protect her, starts to fight with the Sailor. Frances joins in; she's not going to let anyone fight her battles. The Sailor's BUDDY enters the fracas. Everyone's getting hit. As the melee continues we:
A cab pulls up. Frances gets out. She looks weary and has bruise on her cheek. A car is parked in the driveway. She frowns at it, shrugs, and carries her suitcase toward the house.
She enters with her bags, then drops them, stunned. The h is stripped bare. A MAN holding a measuring tape comes ou of the bedroom.
What happened? Who're you?
Who're you?
I live here.
You're Farmer? Oh... Well, look,  they took your stuff out. Moved it  to some hotel, I think.
What?
I'm preparin' it for the next tenant,  he's coming in tomorrow.
Frances stares at him, dumbfounded.
Frances on the phone. Boxes spread out, their contents st over the floor, tables, etc. Frances is going through var piles, again and again, looking for something...
(muttering) God damn it, god damn it... (into phone) Yes, I'll wait, I'm waiting... (to herself) I don't believe this. They can't do  this to me!
She takes a long drink, sifts through a pile, then throws on the bed in disgust. We HEAR a voice on the phone.
(into phone) Barnes? It's my diary! They stole my  fucking diary! Find it, will you?  Find it! God damn it, that's my life!
She slams down the phone.
The crew is idle and the Director paces, muttering:
Never. Never again. I swear, I swear  I will never work with this broad --
Frances, looking pretty hung-over, enters blithely.
You're four hours late! It's insane!  It's unprofessional!
I'd say I'm behaving as professionally  as anyone else in this town.
Where were you?!
Terribly, terribly sorry; I overslept.  What's the name of this fine  entertainment we're all so involved  in?
The Director clenches his fists as though about to punch  her.
(looking blearly at  the slate) Oh yes. "No Escape." That's it.  There's no escape.
She walks to her dressing room as the Director explodes a
Small, cramped; not like the earlier one we saw. The  Hairdresser -- whom we recognize as Tora, the woman who c Bebe's hair -- stands waiting, holding her brushes and lo vexed. Frances enters.
It's about time! You're not the star  on this show, y'know!
Frances sits. Tora begins brushing her hair, yanking Fran head back with each stroke. Building tension...

Of course, it's not up to me to say  anything. I'm just crew... Y'know,  you hair's so fine you'll lose it if  you're not careful. Wonder you all  don't, the things you do to  yourselves. In fact, I think you are  already... Fact, I think you better --
Frances cries out and twists around suddenly. Tora is thr back: stumbling... falling... hitting her jaw against a c
That's it! I'm not taking this any  more! I quit!
She storms out. Tora is left moaning, holding her jaw.
Frances marches across it. Everyone stares.
Goodbye!... goodbye!... goodbye!...
When she reaches the exit door, she turns and bows to the all, grandiloquently.

She's snoring in bed. Face down, spread-eagled. The light on. A whiskey bottle (three-quarters empty), a tumbler (t quarters full), and a bottle of pills sit on the night ta The phone RINGS. She winces, groans, tries to open her ey then squeezes them together: hung over. Her arm flails ou finds the light and turns it off.
Shit.
The phone keeps RINGING. Her arm gropes for it. A loud POUNDING at the door.
What the hell's going on here? (calls) Hold on! (answering phone) Hello... (we HEAR a dial tone) Hello?
The POUNDING at the door becomes violent. Someone's break it down.
Hey!
The door splinters.
What...? Help!
Men stream into the room. Back-lit from the hall they loo like monsters, phantoms. They're carrying sticks. Frances screams and runs naked into the bathroom.
Don't kill me! Don't kill me!
She slams the door on the advancing figures.
Frances leans her weight against the door.
Mama, help me, help me, Mama! Don't  let them kill me!
It's too much for her. She's shoved back, falling to the  floor. The door flies open revealing THREE LARGE COPS. Le at her. Frances clutches at the shower curtain, trying to cover herself.
Get your clothes on.
(crying) You have no right! You have no fucking  right, you bastards! Get the hell  out of here --
Get your clothes on, lady --
GET OUT!
You're under arrest.

Frances is being led to the booking desk. All around her  Photographers snap her picture, and Reporters walk alongs subjecting her to a never-ending barrage of questions. Fr just smokes a cigarette and smiles grimly at the dour-fac SERGEANT facing her.
Name?
I don't believe this! You jerks drag  me down here in the middle of the  night and you don't even know who  the hell I am!
The Photographers laugh.
Age?
Fifteen.
(bristling) Address?
Just put me down as a avg -- a vagrant  vagabond. Come on, this is a joke!  Assault and battery? I barely touched  that bitch!
Occupation?
Frances considers for a moment, then smiles matter-of-fac
Cocksucker.
The Sergeant reddens. Frances laughs as the Photographers snap their shots.
TWO MATRONS escort Frances to her cell. She shakes their  hands off her arms and enters. They slide the door shut.  Photographers press up to the bars. Frances calls after t matrons.
Hey! I'd like to leave a wake-up  call for say, ten? Hey! I'll have my  bread and water in bed!
Frances looks disgustedly at the Photographers and lies d heavily on the cot.
Hey Frances! Why don't you comb your  hair, okay?
...Take me the way I am.

Frances, looking disheveled, dazed, and over-tired from a sleepless night in jail, stands alone before the JUDGE. N to the PROSECUTOR sits Tora, her jaw heavily bandaged, gl at Frances. The spectator's section is packed.
...Is that not true?
(under her breath) Who's writing this guy's lines?
Answer the question! Have you driven  a car since you were placed on  probation?
No, I couldn't get my hands on one.
Have you reported to your Probation  Officer as directed?
I never saw him. Why didn't he show  up?
Did you expect him to look you up?
Why, certainly. I wanted to get a  peek at his face...
Suppressed laughter ripples through the courtroom.
You're on your way to a contempt  citation, young lady.
That's fine with me... (turning to spectators) Get it? Fine. A fine! Hey c'mon,  c'mon, what is this, an audience or  a jury?
Miss Farmer, is it true you fought  with the policeman who arrested you  last night?
Sure it's true. I was fighting for  my country as well as myself.
Miss Farmer, you were advised at the  last hearing that if you took one  drink of liquor or failed to be a  law-abiding citizen --
Frances moves closer to the bench.
Are you telling me you didn't have a  little rum in your pineapple juice  this morning? I can smell it from  here, Your Honor.
The courtroom erupts into surprised laughter.
That's enough!
Frances laughs triumphantly and spears the air with her  finger, pointing at the Judge.
It's the truth! I can smell it from  here -- you old hypocrite!
The laughter grows. The Judge bangs his gavel.

Miss Farmer! In light of your flagrant  disregard for the conditions of your  probation, coupled with the  unwarranted assault on the Plaintiff  here... I am forced to order you to  begin serving a sentence of 180 days  in the County Jail.
Fine!
(rising) You are a deeply troubled young  lady... I only hope you change your  course before it's too late.
The Judge pounds his gavel. Frances is about to say somet when suddenly the realization of what's happening hits he The Judge is leaving the bench. A REPORTER runs out of th room.
(frightened now) Wait a minute... I haven't got a  lawyer...
The Judge ignores this.
(shouting) What I want to know is do I have any  civil rights?
The Judge closes his chambers door behind him. Frances tu slowly. The Matrons are coming toward her.
I want to make a phone call...
She lunges at the Matrons, trying to get past them.
I have a right to make a phone call!
The Reporter is phoning in his story. The hallway is  pandemonium.
(from his notes) "The kleig-lighted road to fame and  fortune is strewn with heartbreak  and despair. Today film star Frances  Farmer, tarnished by alcohol and  drugs" -- 'm I going too fast for  ya?
In the next phone booth we SEE Harry listening to the  Reporter's spiel. He regards the confusion around him wit calm eyes.
They burst open. The Matrons and Two Cops come out carryi Frances. Reporters and Photographers rush past her.
They're stealing my civil rights!  Help me! I'm being kidnapped! Oh  God, help me! Help me!
She suddenly sees the phone booths. Her eyes fill with te her shoulders slump forward and her lower lip begins to  tremble. She no longer struggles.
(to a Matron) Haven't you ever had a broken heart?

The Matron relaxes her grip and gives Frances a handkerch Frances dabs at her eyes... wraps the kerchief around her knuckles... and slugs the Matron in the jaw, sending her  sprawling. Frances runs to the phones.
Oh my God, she's loose!
Frances throws herself at the door of the booth. The Repo is delirious with joy: what a story!
She's attacking your correspondent!  Right here in the Court Building!  Good God, this bitch is crazy! Someone  stop her!
Frances pounds at the door a few more times, then moves t the next booth... into the arms of Harry.
(a whisper) Harry!
Harry shakes his head. Before he can speak, Frances is gr from behind and dragged toward the elevator.
I have a right! I have a right!
(into phone) With what must surely be the final  act of madness, the curtain falls on  Frances Farmer's once promising  career. The crazed blonde who at  27...
Harry opens the door to his booth. The Reporter looks up him.
Hold it a second, Bub...
Harry says not a word, but punches the Reporter hard in t face. The Reporter sags, out like a light. In the confusi no one has noticed a thing. Harry pulls the door shut.

Frances is sitting in a wooden chair. The venetian blinds over the tall windows are almost completely closed. The r is dim and terribly quiet. A WOMAN is murmuring something a kindly-looking JUDGE. Another MAN is standing beside he Frances can't quite make out the words.
...and we feel that this would be  more appropriate.
...a difficult decision, but, I'm  sure, the proper one.
He nods to the other Man who, together with the Woman, tu away from the bench. As they pass in front of one of the  tall windows, Frances recognizes the Woman. It is Alma St
What?
She feels an arm slip around her shoulders and she stiffe Her mother's face appears by hers.
(whispering) It's alright now, little sister,  everything's going to be just fine.
Mama, what's...
Shhh, shhh. You're not going to jail,  Frances. The Judge has put you under  my care. I'll see you get the rest  you need.
You're taking me home!
Two other WOMEN appear at either side of Frances and Lill Lillian tenderly takes her daughter's face in her hands.
(smiling) First things first, little sister.  Trust me.
She kisses Frances on the forehead. Frances looks at the Women. They are smiling understandingly at Lillian. Franc looks a little alarmed.

A wood-panelled station wagon turns the corner of a tree- lined road and heads up toward tall wrought-iron gates. O white-washed wall are black letters: "MEADOW WOOD CONVALE HOME".
