The Station wagon, a similar sign on its door, pul up. The gates swing slowly open, and it travels up a long tree-lined driveway. As it goes by, we see Frances sittin in the back seat between Lillian and one of the Women fro the previous scene. The car heads up toward a large Spanish-style building se back among some trees.
Frances sits in front of a desk nervously smoking a cigar Lillian stands at a window looking out at a broad expanse well-manicured lawn ending at a row of oaks in the distan
Why it's beautiful here! What a view!

Lillian smiles enthusiastically at Frances, who stares  accusingly back: she's not falling for that. An awkward moment of silence. Lillian fidgets, doesn't kn what to say. She is rescued when the door opens and DR.  SYMINGTON (early 30s, glasses, white coat and ingratiatin smile) enters. He holds his right hand out to Frances.
Good afternoon, Miss Farmer. I'm Dr.  Symington.
Frances stares at the proffered hand. Lillian steps in qu and takes it.
Good afternoon, Doctor.
The Doctor winks at Frances and puts a hand on Lillian's  arm.

I'm very pleased to meet you, Mrs.  Farmer. I'm sure we'll have more of  a chance to talk later. Right now I  think it's important that your  daughter have a chance to settle in.  Perhaps it would be best if you said  your goodbyes here.
He smiles pleasantly. Lillian is obviously very put off b the idea. She looks at Frances who stares unseeingly out window.
Oh. Well, I have some background  that you should probably know about  if you're...
I have no doubt, Mrs. Farmer. If  you'll speak to the girl at the desk,  she'll arrange an appointment.
He goes to the door and opens it. Lillian is momentarily a loss, but she acquiesces. She bends down and tightly hu Frances, who pats her on the back a couple of times.
I'll be back real soon, little sister.  You be a good girl.
She waits for a reply and then, getting none, starts out door.
(staring out window) Mama!
Lillian turns back expectantly.
(warningly) ...I want to go home, Mama.
Lillian looks to the Doctor, who nods sympathetically at  her.
You'll see, little sister. Everything  will be fine. The doctors know best.
She goes out and down the hall. The Doctor closes the doo
I find these initial meetings to be  much easier without the concerned  relatives in attendance.
Am I supposed to say 'thank you'?
Thanks are hardly necessary.
Aw, shucks, ma'am. T'weren't nothin'.
I'm glad to see you haven't lost  your sense of humor.
It ain't for lack of trying.
So it seems. May we be serious for a  moment?
(seductively) Why, Doctor! We've only just met!
He reddens ever so slightly and looks away.
I feel I've known you for a long  time... you see, I've followed your  career... you're a fascinating case...  I'm looking forward to resolving  your predicament.
Frances' face begins to set in hard planes.
Oh! Are you really?

Among persons such as yourself,  creative people under great stress,  erratic behavior is not at all  uncommon and certainly nothing to be  ashamed of. It's just that the  neuroses which fuel your talent can  also generate certain character  disabilities which... (can cripple your  ability to function...)
He stops as Frances rises and leans over his desk:
Do you expect me, for one moment, to  believe you have greater insight  into my personality than I do?
Please sit down...
You may discuss my predicament,  Doctor. You may discuss it with anyone  you like, but not with me. I'm not  interested. I can solve my problems  without recourse to a veternarian.
I see.
Besides, I don't want to be what you  want to make me.
And what's that?
Normal. Average.
All right. Will you please sit down  now? (smiling) Symington says.
...Did you really say that?
Just a little joke, Miss Farmer.
This whole thing is a joke!
Stay calm, please.

No, you stay calm, Doctor! But you're  finding that difficult, aren't you? (soft, seductive) Why, are you attracted to me? Perhaps  later, in some of our more intimate  sessions... after we know each other  a little better... (turning harder) and you've torn my personality to  shreds, and I'm weeping and  vulnerable... (very hard) then you'll really get your kicks,  won't you, "Doctor?"
I'll have someone show you to your  room.
Oh, that's good, very professional.  In control. But the tiny beads of  sweat on your upper lip give you  away.
Symington stares at her. With a careful, almost scientifi gesture he moves thumb and forefinger over his lip, then  rubs the two fingers together. Yes, there is sweat.
You really should get some rest now.  Nurse will meet you outside. Good  day.
He pushes a button on his desk and reaches for a folder.  Frances hasn't moved. She gazes at him evenly.
Is there something else?
You didn't say 'Symington says'.
His eyes are very calm now, he smiles at her patronizingl
Symington says.

Small, white, spartan and rather pleasant. Lillian is sta by the window, testing the locks. She turns and goes to t bed, fussing with the pillow, seeming very uncomfortable. She pulls at the corners of the mattress. The door opens and a tall, sullen-looking MATRON walks in Lillian doesn't pay much attention to her.
Not much on hospital corners, are  you?
You Farmer?
Something in her tone makes Lillian look up. The Matron c the door behind her and advances. Lillian assumes her ful height.
Frances is walking with a NURSE. They pass a variety of o patients, some of whom look old or beaten but few of whom seem overtly crazy.
So this is the nuthouse...
The Nurse smiles confidentially at her.
Honey... take my word for it. This  is a resort.
They get to the door and HEAR Lillian's protesting voice:
You have no right!
They enter and SEE the Matron struggling to get Lillian's coat away from her. Lillian pleads with Frances.
Tell them who I am! Tell them who I  am!
Are you crazy? Unhand that woman!  That's Amelia Earhart!
Frances bursts out laughing. The Matron releases Lillian comes for Frances.
A little fluid squirts out the tip.
But what is it?
CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL Frances strapped down on a wh cot. The Nurse is holding the syringe while a THIN NURSE an ATTENDANT stand by.
You've got to tell me what it is!
It's insulin. It throws your body  into shock.
Frances looks at her suspiciously, uncertain whether to  believe this, and turns toward the Nurse with the hypoder
(reassuringly) It's just vitamins.
This sounds more reasonable. Frances relaxes somewhat.
A, C, B-Complex, certain minerals... (inserting hypo) Just stay relaxed... Good, now open  your mouth a sec.

Frances does. The Attendant jams a rubber bar between her teeth. Frances squirms, fights. The Attendant holds the b in place. And the Nurse pushes the plunger on the hypo.  Frances goes rigid. Her eyes widen, her back arches. With loud hoarse cry she starts to convulse. The SCREEN BEGINS FADE into bright white light. She is unconscious. The SCR IS NOW BLANK.

Frances sits beside Lillian on a bench. Other patients wi ground privileges wander aimlessly about. There is an open carpet bag at Lillian's feet and, in her lap, a bundle of letters and telegrams that she's showing Frances. Frances seems restless.

...and here's the one from Duluth. A  war widow with five children. She  works in a defense plant and she's  very worried about you. I answered  her that she shouldn't let worry  over you affect her vital work; and  that you'd be back on the silver  screen in no time.
She hands it to Frances, who lets it drop beside her on t bench.
And here's one from nice Mr. Zeiss.  He says that...
Why are these all opened?
Well, they needed immediate answers,  Frances. It's good manners and good  sense. You shouldn't be bothering  yourself with these right now.
Then why did you bring them?
It's your fan mail, little sister.
(looking off, under  her breath) You kill me, Mama.
What?
Go on...
Frances sighs. She looks for something to divert her  attention.

Frances is alone in the room. The door is ajar. She's sta over Symington's desk, which is empty except for a doodle pad. The doodle she's looking at is extremely bizarre,  sadistic... After a moment, Symington ENTERS holding seve folders. Frances' manner changes very subtly.
...I'm sorry to keep you waiting,  the staff review ran over. Did you  enjoy your mother's visit?
(sitting) Yes. It was very good to see her.
Really? Any problems?
Symington puts the folders in a drawer. All except France

Not at all. She brought me my fan  mail. (a performance) I had no idea there were so many  strangers concerned about me. But I  guess that's the best thing about  working in the movies. You make so  many friends. I want to go back and  show them that the faith they put in  me wasn't a mistake.
You're telling me you feel guilty.
(slightly edgy) No... What I mean is... I'm just  very excited by the prospect of  getting on with my life, that's all.
(after a pause) Do you really believe your mother's  trying to kill you?
(laughing) What?
She told me you said, "Mama, you  want to kill me."
I never said... Oh look. That's just  a figure of speech. She said something  funny, and I said...
And you accused her of tampering  with your mail.
Oh for Christ's...
Frances is wrapping and unwrapping a handkerchief around knuckles. Looks a little crazy. Symington's watching it. stops.
I'm sorry. She misunderstood, that's  all.
But you tell me you had a pleasant  visit and your mother says you were  sullen and uncommunicative. Whom do  you think I should believe?
Doctor, I hate to break this to you,  but my mother is a little batty.
Frances, you're still filled with  anxiety. You feel guilty and hostile  toward your family and friends.  Consequently, I didn't recommend  your release at the staff review.
You what?
Mental illness is an elusive thing,  and though I'm pleased you're feeling  more... capable, it's perhaps  unrealistic to expect you to be  completely cured after so short a  time. Don't you agree?
Frances stares at him. Stunned. Horrified.
(smiling) I'm sure you'll see it my way in the  end.
Dr. Symington, how big is your dick?
Huh?
'Cause if it's long enough, which I  doubt, why don't you wrap it around  and fuck yourself in the ass!
Symington smiles patronizingly.
I want outta here, you understand?  I'm ready to get out! So you go back  there... you go back and you tell  them to let me out!
(calmly) Frances, I'm warning you...

No, I'm warning you! Who do you think  you are, God? You bumble around with  your folders... (she knocks her folder  to the floor) ...and your pencils... (she grabs some pencils  and throws them at  him) ...and your god-damn buttons... (she pounds on the  inter-com; a voice  says, 'Yes, Doctor?') ...all your badges of authority! But  you have no authority! You're nothing!  You're a zero!
She tears open the door. Two huge ORDERLIES are waiting.  Frances tries to barrel past, but they easily restrain he
Doc?
Symington sits forward, his hands smoothing his hair. Frances smiles sarcastically at him:
Symington says...
(tonelessly) Sedate her.
They haul her away.

A few PATIENTS stroll about, visiting with relatives. Fra lies on a chaise lounge. She's wearing a robe and dark  glasses, a big hat, and she seems to be sleeping. THE CAM APPROACHES. Her hair is a mess, her skin splotchy. And  something is moving: her hand... one finger on one hand i moving in agitated little bursts. We realize she is not  sleeping at all...
Hi there. How 'bout a walk in the  woods?
She looks to one side and sees him. Frowns. Takes off her glasses and runs her fingers nervously through her hair.
Oh my God, I look awful.
(friendly) You've looked a whole lot better.  C'mon.
Frances and Harry walking in a relatively secluded area. glances around continuously... suspiciously.

They're doin' stuff to me, Harry.  Can you see it? You feel it? They're  putting stuff in my food or something,  my water, and they're using it to  put thoughts in my head. You  understand? They're trying to re- arrange what's in my head, they're  trying to drive me crazy! Oh, Harry!
She breaks down and weeps on Harry's shoulder. Harry look around warily.
I can't stay here anymore, you  understand? I can't, I can't. I gotta  get home. I gotta get somewhere else,  anywhere, okay?
Harry nods, squeezes her arm firmly -- a warning -- as a  white-coated ATTENDANT APPROACHES. Frances straightens up
Oh, Miss Farmer! Time for your bath,  Miss Farmer!
(urgent whisper) Listen: to the left. Straight through  the trees and over the wall to your  left. My car is there.
The Attendant reaches them.
(as if to a child) It's time for your bath!
Oh good. I love my baths.
Come along now.
Frances starts to move off with the Attendant. For an ins Harry -- and we -- wonder if she really is crazy.
Frances! Did you hear what I said?
She turns. The Attendant turns. She smiles sweetly, madly
Of course, Harry.
The Attendant is between her and Harry. We SEE her face t dark. She shoves the Attendant toward Harry and shouts:
(fiercely) Over the walls!
She runs. The Attendant staggers toward Harry, who knocks him down with two punches. ANOTHER ATTENDANT runs up. Har whips out an icepick and brandishes it at them:
You want crazy? I'll show you crazy!
The Attendants hold their ground. Harry runs after France
Frances and Harry crash through bushes, come to a high wa
(offering to lift her) Here.

Frances hugs him tightly, kisses him. He lifts her by the waist, and she grabs the top of the wall and hauls hersel up. Harry joins her. We SEE, over the wall, a Lincoln Zep waiting on a dirt road. Harry and Frances jump down as we HEAR the Two Attendants burst through the underbrush and  haul themselves up. As their heads pop over the top of th wall, they see the Lincoln disappearing down the road in cloud of dust...

Harry, eyes bleary and shoulders hunched, tries to concen on the road ahead. The RADIO DRONES quietly, a lazy saxop ballad. After a while, there's movement in the back seat Frances sits up. She yawns and stretches as Harry watches her in the mirror.
Evening, gorgeous.
(yawning) That sure looks like fun... (leaning over front  seat) You know how long it's been since I  was behind the wheel?
Forget it, Frances. You're not  driving.
Have I told you how mean you're  turning, York?
Harry smiles. Frances climbs over the seat and starts to  fiddle with the radio.
Where are we, mean man?
Couple hours from Idaho. We'll cut  across to Montana. I've got friends  there with a ranch.
I should've known...
What?
This is another one of your schemes  to get me off alone...
That's right.
(smiling) ...Take advantage of me.
Harry laughs. They pass a poster: "BUY WAR BONDS!" Frances stares at it
I don't think I'd be much good in a  war...
Whattaya think you're in now?
(sleepily) I don't know. Not a war exactly.  It's more a... a misapprehension  maybe...
Huh?
A misunderstanding, people taking  the wrong meaning from things. I  wasn't declaring war, Harry. I was  just saying my prayers.
Harry looks at her quizzically.
Who to?
Beat.
Harry, I have to go home. I have to  talk to Mama.
Frances, you're fulla drugs. You  don't know what you're saying. Who  do you think put you into Meadow  Wood? Your mother thinks you're crazy  and she'll keep on thinking it as  long as it suits her.
(sitting up) No, she just didn't want me going to  jail, that's all.
Yeah? She's a shark, Frances. I'm  not taking you there, and that's  that!
She rubs his neck and his attitude seems to soften. She looks at him fondly, thoughtfully.
You know something, Harry?
I guess.
Aside from meanness, you're almost  perfect. There's only one other thing  wrong with you.
What's that?
You can't drink.
The Lincoln is parked beside a few other cars.
Frances and Harry sit at a table cluttered with empty gla The JUKEBOX PLAYS, a few COUPLES dance. Frances is gulpin down a tall Scotch.
(wincing/grinning) Ohhh, that's lousy Scotch!
(calling drunkenly) Hey! Another shot for the lady and a  double for me!
What a man!
Hey, you're a good quarter-horse,  kid, but you can't go a route of  ground.
(hoisting her glass) To quarter-horses.
No. To thoroughbreds.
He knocks back his drink.
A hand puts a nickel in, and we HEAR Bing Crosby singing  "Love Is So Terrific." We PAN across the dance floor, whe Harry and Frances are dancing.
Love is so terrific Such a funny  feeling Makes you want to cuddle And  coo...
Frances squeals with delight when she hears the song. She holds Harry forcefully and starts to lead him around the  floor. Harry starts to sing along:
Makes you sentimental, Makes you  kinda gentle Ouch! (Frances pinches Harry) Terrific thing.
Around them an infection is spreading: all the women are  leading their men. For an instant it is magical, liberati She leans her head against his shoulder.
Why are you always leaving me, Harry?
Huh?
You should stickaround sometimes.  Look out for me.
Look, Frances, I'm only gonna ask  this one time. I mean it. I swear  after this, I'll never ask again:  Will you marry me?

(after a long pause) I know a thing or two about marriage.  You... you understand me more than  anyone, Harry... maybe even more  than Mama. But... you're too important  to me. I'd fail you. I don't know  how or why, but I would. And that's  a chance I just can't take. Do you  understand?
(a bitter smile) Well... I'll act like I do until I  do.
They are silent for a moment.
There's just one more thing.
What's that?
Will you marry me?
She laughs happily. He joins her, but his seems a little  forced. She leans her head on his shoulder and holds him tight. T dance...
The Lincoln, Harry at the wheel, drives up and stops. Har shakes his head.
It's not too late to keep going, up  to Vancouver? Be the smartest thing.
Thanks, Harry, really, but... I can't  explain it. She's my mother. She's  just... I can't give up on her that  easy.
You give up on her?
Yeah. It's just... something I gotta  do, I guess.
(smiling warmly) Frances, You're crazy.
(whispers) I know. Don't tell anyone.
He laughs. We SEE Lillian come out onto the porch with  uncharacteristic trepidation.
Anyway... if you need me...
(warmly) I got your number, Mister Man.
She gets out, waves to him, and walks toward the house. H drives off. As Frances reaches the top step, Lillian sudd opens her arms:
(nervous, forced) Welcome home, little sister.
Frances and Lillian enter. On the sofa sits Alma Styles.  Alma and Lillian seem slightly furtive. Caught in the act
Well, who have we here...?
(anxiously) Frances, you remember my lawyer,  Alma Styles?
Hello, Frances. You seem to be having  quite a time of it.
I called Alma because I think we'll  need...
Frances, the doctors at Meadow Wood  have petitioned the court for your  return. Your mother has asked me to  intervene so you can stay here.
I swear I didn't know what they were  doing to you. I wouldn't have let  them...
She bursts into tears. Frances takes her in her arms and  rocks her like a child.
It's okay, Mama. It's okay.

You realize, of course, your mother  is now your legal guardian. In the  eyes of the law, you no longer have  any rights as an adult. You're going  to have to hold your tongue and be  selective about whom you mix with.  That man who drove you here, for  instance --
You leave him out of this!
Frances, please don't...
Never mind. We won't have to worry  about him much longer.

Harry pulls up at a stop sign. He rubs his forehead weari as a car crosses the intersection. It stops dead in front him. Another pulls up alongside. Another behind. Harry th about this. His hand slides down slowly under the seat. W SEE the handle of his ice pick. Harry turns to smile at t MAN in the next car. The Man flashes an FBI badge, points revolver:
(smiling) How ya doin', Al?
You got the wrong guy. Name's Slocum.
No, it ain't. And it ain't Harry  York, neither.
Look, I'm tellin' you...
The FBI Man pulls the hammer back on the revolver. ANOTHE MAN opens the passenger door.
I'd give you till ten, Al, but we  ain't got the time.

Judge Hillier walking... out of the chamber and down a  corridor. His stride is long, his demeanor purposeful. Th corridor leads into a courtroom. Harry standing at attent We hear Hillier climb onto the bench and be introduced by the court official. Harry stares up at the judge.

Alvin Hanson, a.k.a. Ronald Burns,  Thomas Slocum, Harry York... Mr.  Hanson, this warrant has been  outstanding for many years. Normally  that circumstance would prompt me  toward leniency, but the crime you  committed -- inciting to riot -- and  the cause you sought to promote -- a  worker's rebellion -- are such  anathemas to this court that I feel  compelled to mete out the full  sentence. I only wish it were longer. (slamming gavel) Six months in the state penitentiary.
Frances sits at the piano playing "You Are My Sunshine".  Lillian is lounging on the couch, leafing happily through her scrapbook.
Frances, play 'Flow Gently Sweet  Afton'.
Frances' brows mesh.
Oh Mama, I'm so... tired of that  song.
Please. I want you to. It would make  me so happy.
Frances sighs and begins to play it. Lillian scrunches do and begins to hum along.
It's just a flow gently sweet Afton  day. Life has been so good to me.  Why, I have just about everything  one could wish... but I still have  so many blank pages in my scrapbook.
She smiles warmly at Frances. Frances abruptly stops play
I think I need a little air.
What's wrong?
Nothing. I think I'll just go out  for awhile.
Where are you going?
For a walk, Mama. Just a walk.
She gets up and Lillian rouses herself.
How long will you be?
Not long.
Frances goes down the hall for her coat. Lillian follows  part way.
(smiling) I'll have lunch ready by one.
I'll be back.
At one. Promise?
Sure.
Frances returns wearing the coat. Lillian half-blocking h path.
Say you promise.
I promise I'll... I promise, Mama.
Lillian nods, moves aside. As Frances heads for the door:
You know, the surest way to lose an  appetite, is to drink, little sister.
(exiting) Yes, Mama.
I don't want you drinking, Frances.
Yes, Mama.
Lillian enters and re-establishes herself on the couch wi a happy smile. She begins to hum "Flow Gently Sweet Afton
DERELICTS sleep on broken couches and armchairs. In a cor by a pay phone Ernest Farmer sits at a rickety desk piled high with briefs. Frances sits across from him. They've b talking.
...So what do you think?
I don't know, honey. Your mother has  such big plans for you.
I know that, Dad, but --

What you have to understand, Francie,  is that she... well... she wanted so  much for herself too, and for me,  and she never really got to... The  only time I ever saw her happy was  if her name was in the papers... but  she could have been... if times were  different she could have been a  politician or... I don't know.
But Dad, I'm asking about me. What  do you think I should do?

(after a pause) Well, Francie, sometimes after you  get your hands on something you want,  it just doesn't look the same. Then  you have to be real smart to know if  you should hold onto it because it's  all you've got... or just let it go.  This is the way of things, but I  guess you already know that.
Dad... whatever I decide, will it be  okay with you?
Always. Always.
Frances rises from her chair, looking around the room to  hide her tears. Ernest rises too.
I'm sorry, I... I don't have a desk  in my room, and... (it's not a proper  office)
I don't care, Dad. I love you.
I love you too, Francie.
They look at each other across the desk for an uncomforta moment, then Frances slowly leaves. He looks sadly after  her.
Frances exits and starts across the road. Ernest comes to the window to watch her leave. It is raining and the wate on the glass distorts his view.
Lillian is straightening up Frances' room, rearranging th to suit herself. She hears the door slam downstairs.
I'm back, Mama.
(coming into hall) Oh Frances, do I have news for you!  Guess who --

(excited) Wait, Mama, wait. I have something  to tell you. I've decided... well...  I'm not going to make movies anymore.  I thought that's what I wanted, and  I went after it with all my soul,  the way you taught me, but I was  miserable, Mama, and it nearly killed  me. So now... now it's over. I want  a different kind of life, something...  simple. I want to live someplace  quiet and peaceful... in the country  maybe, and I'll have dogs and cats --  I feel so light suddenly, so clear  for the first time in... It's going  to be okay, Mama, I know it. And I  love you.
She goes to hug her mother, but Lillian has changed. Fran news has chilled her.
(coming down stairs) Don't... talk crazy.
Mama...?

(entering living room) They want you back! Your agent called  today! Don't you understand? He's  sending the scripts. He wants to fly  up here in a week with the publicity  people! Frances, you can't do this  to your fans! Why, they've been  praying for you all through this  nightmare. You can't turn your back  on them now! Look at this fan mail  I've been answering!
She points to a stack of letters on the table.
Haven't you heard what I said?
I told him to come up! I told him  you wanted to show them all that  there's nothing wrong with you any  more, that you're completely cured!
I'm not cured. I was never sick!  They had no business putting me in  there! My only responsibility is to  myself now!
You... you selfish, selfish child.  At least talk to him, hear what he  has to say.
No!
You want to throw it all away, is  that it? You had everything, little  sister. Beauty... a brilliant  career... a wonderful husband. You  were a movie star!
Mama, shut up!
And now you're throwing everything  away? You're gonna be a nobody!  Nobody! You know what that's like?!
(sudden realization) You... You'd send me back, wouldn't  you? You would.
Frances grabs her coat.
Where are you going?
I'm going out!
You're not going anywhere!
Yes, I am, and you can't stop me!  You can't tell me what to do, mother.  I'm a grown woman, and I can decide  about my own life.
Frances!
They're wrestling, Lillian trying to prevent her from lea
Don't you try and stop me. Don't you  dare!
She grabs Lillian's wrists and twists them, throws her ba
If you follow me, Mama, I swear I'll  fucking kill you!
Frances storms out. Lillian sits back in the chair, sudde looking very old. She massages her wrists...
That's it. You've done it now, little  sister.
Dark. Blinds drawn. We SEE a single light with a green sh HEAR the soft coo of Lillian's voice. The CAMERA SHIFTS  gradually onto her earnest face.

All my life, I've tried to live up  to my parents' example. To have the  independence of mind and fortitude  of spirit that have made this country  great. I taught that to Frances:  Speak out. Aspire. Make something of  yourself, something -- (to be proud of)
(bored) Yes, yes, Mrs. Farmer --
Frances has always been a  battleground, Lillian.
DR. DOYLE, a psychiatrist, and the others are seated with Judge Hillier around a table.
The point is: it's your opinion that  Frances is getting steadily worse?
Well... yes.
Doyle fills in a line on the printed form before him.
And you feel you're unable to control  her any longer?
No... I mean, yes, Doctor.
Alma holds up Lillian's bruised wrists as evidence.
And the only course open to you is  to commit your daughter for a period  of time to a mental institution?
Well, Alma told me that...
Alma looks coolly at Lillian.
...Yes.
Hillier nods slightly, approvingly, toward Alma.
(closing his folder) I believe that's all I need to know  about Miss Farmer.
I think in all future documents she  should be referred to as Mrs. R. H.  Richardson.
Her married name?
Yes. It's less recognizable. I'm  sure you'd prefer to keep unpleasant  publicity to a minimum.
...Oh yes.
Now. Can you tell us where we might  find Frances?
It's late. Frances stands at the bar acting out a joke fo small audience of devoted DRINKERS.

...Looking for a drink, and the town  is deserted, he can't understand it.  Finally he finds a bar, goes in --  the place is empty, bartender's  closing up. Salesman says, 'Gimme a  martini.' Bartender's real nervous,  he says, 'No, no, no, I gotta close.  Big Otis is coming to town.'
Behind them is a large window covered by a gauzy curtain. the street a police car cruises slowly past.

Salesman says, 'I don't care. I gotta  have a martini.' So the bartender  fixes him a martini real fast, grabs  his money, and runs out the back.  Salesman sits there sipping his  martini,... he's got the bar all to  himself... Then he hears it. This  big roaring in the street.  RRRAAAAAAA!!! (stomping her feet) Gigantic footsteps... coming closer.  Stopping.
We SEE the police car again... It stops out front.

Enormous hands reach in, grab the  swinging doors and rip them off their  hinges. This huge man stomps in.  Picks up a chair and hurls it over  the bar, smashing the mirror --  whiskey and glass flying everywhere.
TWO COPS appear at the window, looking in.

He turns to the salesman: 'What the  hell're you doing in here!' Salesman  says, 'I'm just drinking a martini.'  'Oh yeah?' the guy says. 'Well you  better get outa here! Big Otis is  coming to town!'
Everyone laughs. A long moment of enjoyment. Then Frances turns, looks out the window and sees the cops.

Hillier behind the bench. Doyle sits at a table with Alma Styles. A COURT RECORDER taps out his notes in an odd, je style. (NOTE: This scene is INTERCUT, where appropriate,  with shots of FRANCES in a bare room, wearing a strait  jacket.)

...From her history, it's apparent  the patient suffers from a paranoid  reaction with pronounced egotism.  Her violent responses have recently  included aggression against her  mother. In view of the deep-seated  nature of her ailments and her failure  to respond satisfactorily to insulin  shock, it is my opinion she may  ultimately require permanent  institutional care.
(to Styles) Counsellor, as Guardian ad litem for  Mrs. Richardson, do you waive jury  trial?
Yes, your Honor.
She signs a paper which is passed to Hillier.

Having heard the testimony of a  legally qualified and reputable  physician... and being further  satisfied of the truth of all matters  set forth in the certificates of  said physician, I do hereby order  that the said Mrs. R. H. Richardson,  an insane person, be confined to the  Western State Hospital for the Insane  at Steilacoom.
He bangs his gavel.
So ordered! Are the gentlemen from  Steilacoom present?

Huge, dark-red brick buildings with barred windows, loom of the fog and trees. A van pulls up to the front entranc Two MEN get out, open the back doors and assist Frances o She is strapped into a strait-jacket. She yells and strug violently but a piercing SCREAM stops her. She looks up a the building. From a top floor window, a thin, white hand protrudes fro the bars and waves "hello".

Frances is dragged kicking and screaming down the shiny  linoleum-covered hallway. There are many patients here,  talking to imaginary birds, laughing at unheard jokes. A of them notice Frances, most do not. The two Orderlies ar at a door and throw it open. A bare 6'10' room is reveale with a narrow cot and no windows. Frances is pushed insid and the door locks shut with a resounding click.

A MEDICAL STUDENT wheels a small electrical machine up to table. On the table Frances is securely strapped down. TW DOCTORS grease Frances' temples and put two metal electro on them. The electrodes are connected to the machine.
What's she getting, anyway?
Standard series to start.
Fifteen?
Doctor #2 nods and jams a rubber bar into Frances' mouth. The Medical Student steps forward.
Can I push the button on this one?
Doctor #1 shoots a silent query to Doctor #2.
Sure.
The Medical Student pushes the button with great gravity. Frances' body immediately begins to convulse. It seems as it will never stop.

Beds three inches apart. Women patients lie on them in va stages of madness and decay. Some are bound to their beds with coarse cloth strips. One bed is empty, the bonds che through. We find Frances sitting on the floor staring at hissing radiator. Her lips are caked with blood. Her eyes are glazed. She is dreaming. Or remembering...
A scene from one of her movies or plays. Soundless. She l radiant, vivacious, alive...

A NURSE ushers Frances and two ATTENDANTS into a sparse t room with dilapidated plumbing and fungus growing between the tiles. In the center are three steel baths with hammo suspended above them. The Attendants strap Frances into a bath as Dr. Doyle enters.

(speaking with  difficulty) Doctor, it may sound odd, but I  believe I've profited from my stay  here. It's just what I've needed, to  get away like this. But I'm  recuperated now. I've had lots of  time to think and I've made a few  decisions about my life. I'm ready  to get on with it.
I know you believe that.
...Don't you?

I'm afraid not. You see, we observe  things that you're unaware of: signs,  indicators. Your problem cuts very  deep, Frances, and we have to get at  that deeper stuff so that when you  do get out, you'll really feel secure.  Does that make sense?
The Attendants lower her into the empty tub.
No. Cut this runaround, Doctor. I  know better.
(smiling) Listen to yourself, Frances. The  resistance, the anger in your voice.
(tightly) You... I'm sorry, forgive me. Doctor,  tell me honestly, what do I have to  do to get out of here?
Be patient, that's all. Take an  interest in your treatment and don't  dwell on your resentments. You'll be  yourself again, I assure you.
...I see.
We'll talk more about this. I'll see  you later.
One question. If I'm not myself now,  just who do you think I am?
The Doctor smiles sympathetically.
We'll talk.
As he turns to leave, Frances laughs triumphantly. The tw Attendants lower her into the bath and begin to fill it w ice-cold water.
What the hell!
They shove a rubber bit between her teeth. She immediatel spits it out and defiantly starts to sing in order to kee her teeth from chattering.

Everyone eating gruel. A parade of lunatics. The edge of  incipient violence is palpable. Frances eats listlessly.  Others are playing with their food, devouring it ravenous fondling each other. Suddenly a call starts up at the far end of the hall. Other voices join in. At first we don't  understand it, but gradually the words become clear:
Come and get it! Come and get it!  Come and get it!
The whole hall joins in. The Nurses make no effort to sto it. Others at Frances' table smile at her, try to push he to her feet. When they succeed, the hall breaks into appl and a new chaotic chant:
We want Frances! We want Frances!

The chant is quickly silenced by hushing sounds. Everyone watching Frances. She climbs up on her bench. Her eyes ar glazed, her face expressionless. This feels like some kin of automatic behavior. She takes an exaggerated posture a speaks in almost a whisper:
Come and get it...
The hall breaks into riotous applause, catcalls, stomping Frances climbs down from her bench. That was the entire  performance.

Two dark FIGURES move stealthily along the shadow of the  main building. A little ways ahead, a door opens, sending shaft of light across the ground. The two Men duck back i the shadows. Five young SOLDIERS EXIT, paying off and wav goodbye to one of the Orderlies. The door closes. They he off down the road laughing and joking together. The two Men emerge from the shadows and approach the door They try the handle. It opens. The first one in is Harry, followed by the other Man carrying a rolled-up bundle.

We SEE Harry and the other Man, now wearing a white Docto coat, walking quickly down a dim hallway. They come to a  large door with a barred window. The Man fiddles with a  keyring and unlocks the door. They enter. We HEAR the doo lock behind them.

Just inside the door the Doctor flicks on a flashlight an they walk down the center of the room. The beam of light  sweeps over women PATIENTS in their cots, crammed side-by side. Some are asleep, others stare blankly at the ceilin A few smile invitingly at the two Men, whispering obsceni The light falls on a bedraggled woman hunched over in a c between the wall and a cot. It is Frances. Harry goes to  her, putting his arms around her. She is very heavily sed Tears spring to Harry's eyes.
(whispering) Frances! Frances!
Who?
Frances, it's me, Harry?
...Touch me again and I'll kill you,  you pig.
Watch out, Harry. Let me look her  over.
Harry is on the verge of tears.
Oh, God! Let's get her out of here  tonight, right now! Let's take her  with us!
The hearing's tomorrow. If she gets  out legally, they can't come after  her.
Look at her! She'll never pass that  sanity test tomorrow...

I'm taking care of that, Harry. Just  hold her. (pulling a hypodermic  from his pocket) Reserpine. I guarantee you this'll  clear her head. She'll wake up feeling  smart and sailright through the  hearing.
Harry holds her around the shoulders and straightens out arm. Frances starts to struggle and moan loudly.
Yeah... she knows about these. Shut  her up.
Harry glares at the Doctor, but puts a hand over her mout and the Doctor injects her. Her arm is covered with sores

(tenderly) You'll be okay, honey. He's just  givin' you something to make you  think, so that tomorrow you can tell  'em what they want to hear, okay?  Tell 'em you were crazy as a loon  and they cured you and you're  grateful.
The Doctor withdraws the hypo and massages her arm.
This stuff takes pretty quick. Let's  go.
(grabbing Harry) Please! Take me!
Other women in the ward cry out: "Take me! Take me!!"
(pulling Harry) Let's get out of here! I'll lose my  job!
Frances, we gotta do it this way.  Just remember tomorrow, remember  what I told you. What're you gonna  tell 'em?
(groggily) I'm grateful... grateful.
I'm grateful! I'm grateful!
(very worried) Harry!
I gotta go now.
Harry, please!
The two Men come out and the Doctor quickly locks the doo
We're all square now, Harry. Right?
All square, Doc.
Good. 'Cause I don't want to see you  again.
Frances' face appears at the tiny barred window. We can j hear her:
I love you, Harry. I love you.
I love you too, Frances.
Behind Frances we HEAR the Women screaming: "I love you,  Harry!" The Doctor takes Harry's arm and pulls him down t corridor.
Frances turns to face the women in their cots. Collects  herself. Looks repentant. She is practicing tomorrow's sp
I realize now that I was a very sick  woman.
Sick! She's sick!
I couldn't relate to others in a  normal way.
(playful warning) She's... not... normal...!
The others laugh. We realize that if Frances can handle t she can sail through it tomorrow. The catcalls gradually  diminish as she concludes her speech.

And I was not taking responsibility  for my actions. But now, thanks to  your treatment, I feel ready to face  myself, ready to resume the career  which I so single-handedly shattered.  I only hope... I hope I can make you  all proud of me. Thank you. Thank  you so much.
The room is silent now. A very odd moment. To their  astonishment, the other patients seem to believe her...

The vegetable garden is overgrown, the paint peeling. The house is in disrepair, but we can tell from the freshly-m lawn that some effort has recently been made... A car pulls up. Frances kisses Ernest on the cheek and ge out. As he drives off, she walks into the yard and looks  around, heaves a sigh; she's home. Then Christmas lights  spring on over the porch. Lillian comes out grinning broa followed by REPORTERS. Frances blanches.
Frances sits on the couch next to Lillian. They're sippin tea and answering questions. Frances is uncomfortable.
Of course, she hasn't anything  definite in mind.
No. No, it all depends on what offers  I get.
Who did your hair, Frances?
She touches it shyly. It's swept up in a continental styl
Well, I like to try different styles.  Sometimes if you're old-fashioned  enough, you find you're modern. Right,  Mama?
Lillian laughs.
What do you think of all this, Mrs.  Farmer?
It's a miracle. Just a miracle.
The porch light goes out. Shadows pass over the curtained windows. Across the street a match flares. Harry is leani against a tree. He lights a cigarette and settles back to wait.
Lillian walks from room to room turning off lights. Franc is neatly stacking the dessert dishes on a tray. Very  domestic, out of character. She carries the tray into the kitchen.
Oh, just leave those things for now.
No, Mama, I'll take care of it. I'll  wash them in the morning.
Lillian smiles warmly at her.
You know, little sister, I never  resented you for refusing to see me  in the... the hospital. I knew you  had to manage on your own before you  could come back.
Thank you for understanding, Mama.
Lillian links her arm with Frances' and they go upstairs  together.
Little sister, I don't want you to  feel any rush to get back to work. I  want you to rest... for a while  anyway.
I will, I promise.
They hug each other.
Good night, dear.
Lillian waits until Frances has shut her door before clos hers.
The front door opens and Frances, suitcase in hand, slips out onto the porch. She eases the door shut behind her,  tiptoes down the steps and, without looking back, starts  down the road.
Frances rounds the corner, then sees him: Harry, standing his car, smiling.
Where to?
Oh Harry...
She approaches him tentatively.
This is it, kid. This is our chance.  When you got a chance, you better  take it.
Yeah. I don't know.
You don't need to screw around  anymore. You don't need Dwayne Steele  or Odets or your mother. You need  me.

I know, but... There were so many  people in there, Harry. Every time I  turned around someone was pressing  against me... watching, looking over  my shoulder, touching me, grabbing,  sticking things into me. When I feel  somebody near me now... anybody...  my skin starts to crawl.
Long beat. She turns and stares at him sadly.
You can't change the things they did  to me, Harry. Only I can do that...  by myself.
He nods slowly.
Been a lot of years, you know. A  long time waiting. For what? End up  feeling like a sap.
Oh please, Harry... don't even think  it. You're the only person who ever...  It's just... Can't you wait for me?
I don't know.
(getting frantic) Yes you do. If you love me you can  wait, right? A month, six months,  whatever it takes.
Right. Except... time has a way of --
No, Harry, it's not time, it's us.  You and me. And I'm telling you now  that I'll come to you, okay? I'll  find you. I will.
(smiles wistfully) I hope so, Frances.
They hug. Together for an instant. Then she shivers as if the contact were too much.
(disentangling) I'm sorry.
He nods, looks at her.
I'll be seeing you, kid.
He turns and walks slowly to his car.

Barren desert. The middle of nowhere. A lone male HITCHHI poor, stands at a crossroads. A car coming the wrong dire raises dust along the highway. It slows, stops, and lets  Frances out. She is now dressed in jeans and a workshirt. She has a heavy tan. She glances across at the Hitchhiker and nods casually. H responds in kind. A relaxed silence follows. Two stranger passing. His voice, when he speaks, is gentle, calm:
Pretty morning.
(nods) It's always beautiful at this time.  Peaceful...
And no people.
Yes.
Beat.
Where you goin'?
Wherever they're going, I'm going.
Yeah, I know what that's like...  Where you been?
Well, I was picking fruit with some  migrant workers until...
She stops. She sees now that the car heading toward her i cop car. She averts her face... then tries to hide her  gesture.
What's the matter?
Frances sighs as the cop car speeds away.
They're looking for you, huh?
She's uncertain whether to trust him. Takes the plunge:
Yeah.
What'd you do?
You know, I've never been able to  figure that out.
He laughs. She shivers slightly, pulls her clothes around her. He takes out a small flask and offers, no strings:
I've got a little whiskey here, warm  you up.
She smiles, truly grateful:
Thank you.
Then she sees a ball of dust nearing... a car on his side
Wait. Maybe they'll pick you up.
The car stops. Its lights flashing. COPS jump out.
Shit!
Run!
She does. She's pursued. The Hitchhiker makes an effort t impede the Cops' progress, but is tossed aside. The Cops slowly, inevitably, gaining on her.
Frances and Ernest walk out the door followed by a portly SHERIFF. He watches them get in Ernest's car and drive of His expression says very clearly: I'm glad that's over wi
Ernest's at the wheel, Frances at his side. Silence, then
Dad...? Why don't you stop at a side  road and let me out?
Ernest writhes slightly with discomfort.
Francie, you know I can't do that.
Why? It's such a simple thing. You  just let me out and I disappear down  a road and you never have to see me  again.
They'll just catch you again, Francie.  Besides, your mother will know.
We SEE them approaching a side road.
Dad, here! You don't have to stop,  just slow down. You can tell Mama I  jumped out. She knows that's the  kind of thing I'd do. She won't blame  you.
But I gave her my word. Besides,  she's still your legal guardian. My  hands are tied.
They are nearer the side road.
You know where you're taking me. You  know what she'll do. Just give me a  minute, slow down, give me an instant  for once in your life, please?
Please, Francie...
(pleading) Daddy!
They pass the side road. It disappears behind them. All t life seems to drain from Frances.
I'll try to protect you, Francie. I  will, I'll talk to her. We'll have a  real talk.
Frances buries her face in her hands.
Are you... are you hungry?
I pity us, Dad. I pity us both.

Lillian is sitting on the couch, waiting. We HEAR A CAR P UP outside and stop. Doors slam. Steps come up the walk a onto the porch. The door opens and Frances and Ernest ent Lillian rises to face her daughter.
(coldly) Do I go right away or do I have time  to take a bath?
I was hoping for a kind word, little  sister.
You were hoping for a kind word?!  You're my mother! You're supposed to  nourish me! Support me!
I have!
Through the window we SEE a white van pull up outside.

No! All you've done is try to break  my spirit, try to turn me into you!  But I'm not you, mother, and I never  will be, and thank god for it! (to Ernest) That goes for you too! And frankly,  I don't know how, with the two of  you, I turned out as sane as I am -- (to the MEN IN WHITE  COATS who are at the  door) Wait right there, gentlemen, I'll be  with you in a minute... and believe  me, I don't want to stay here one  second longer than I have to! (turning back) But I've got to tell you, Lillian,  that one day before you die, you  will realize what you've done and  hang your head in shame. In shame!
But what -- (have I done?)

No! You're not talking now. You  listen. You can send me away, Lillian,  you can pretend I'm crazy and pretend  I'm still your little girl who can't  take care of herself, but one thing  you can't pretend anymore. You can't  pretend I love you because I don't.  I can't. Not after what you've done  to me. Because you see... I'm still  me... I'm trying real hard all this  time to be me... and you, 'little  sister', you haven't been any help  at all. (walking out the door) Okay, boys, I'm ready.
The way she goes out that door we know she's never coming back.

The ward is a huge room packed with nearly naked women, t hair cropped very short. The walls are corrugated tin nai to bare wood framing. The place looks like an enormous to shed. The SOUND OF GARBLED VOICES and SCREAMING never sto These are the forgotten ones... beyond hope. Everyone her has lost any notion of what they might have once been. Th faces are slack, only their eyes glow with an animal fero Some wander aimlessly about, unheeding of others who are  pushing, kicking and screaming at them. Many squat in the dirt by the walls, mired in their own urine and excrement chanting wordlessly to themselves. Some appear lifeless,  their prone bodies shoved out of the way. Some women are  involved in violent sex with themselves or each other, so in mindless fist-fights. In a far corner we SEE a group o men in various military and medical uniforms, their backs us, facing the wall, grouped around something. We HEAR th cheering and laughing and joking, slapping each other on back. We SLOWLY MOVE CLOSER and can see over their shoulders th object of their hilarity. It's Frances, lying naked and s eagled on the floor. Four hospital ATTENDANTS pin her arm and legs. A SOLDIER, his pants down around his ankles, is squirming violently on top of her. Frances' eyes are open but glazed, her face turned away from her attacker. She i passive and unresisting. She is reciting to herself, over and over.
We shall hear the angels, we shall  see the whole sky all diamonds...
Two of the SOLDIERS, waiting their turn, are smoking  cigarettes and chatting idly.
...Best deal I ever made. Twenty  bucks to fuck a fuckin' movie star.
Yeah, it's worth it I guess.
What's she saying, anyway?
Who knows. She's crazy, ain't she?
Frances keeps reciting as one rapist gets off. The Soldie cheer as another quickly takes his place.

A heavy snow is falling. From the corrugated-tin Violent  Ward, a thin white hand protrudes from a narrow window to catch a snowflake. As it opens and closes, capturing individual flakes, a VO BEGINS TO SING "You Are My Sunshine...". We recognize Fra voice, still surprisingly strong and steady.
TWO NURSES discuss Frances' condition as we SEE, backgrou that she is getting electroshock treatments from a pair o doctors.
I don't know why they even bother.  She's had enough of this to knock  sense into a bull elephant.
Yeah?
(nods) I checked the files. This one holds  the record for shock treatments.  Four hundred seventeen and no end in  sight.
(wincing) You're kidding.
(indicating the doctors) Yeah, well, you know doctors. They  sure hate to use that word.
What?
'Incurable.'
Frances, barely conscious, lies strapped to a bed. Doyle an ORDERLY approach her. Doyle nods toward her as if to s that one. He and the Orderly unstrap her.
(to Doyle) Harry? Oh Harry, I knew you'd come.  I love you, Harry. I love... Take me  home, Harry.
We'll get you home, Frances.
Thank you, Harry.
She's untied. The Orderly helps her up onto a gurney. She lies down. Doyle nods to the Orderly, who starts push her. She is wheeled out and down:
Past other patients, doctors, etc. We see some of this fr her point of view. She goes through two swinging doors, down another hall... the end of which a man opens a door. She is pushed onto a
She is wheeled into a row... between two other patients. the background we HEAR a voice:

One merely inserts the leucotome  beneath the eyelid and presses up  into the prefrontal lobe, manipulating  it so as to sever the nervous  connections between the thalamofrontal  radiation and the body of the brain.
The lights are bright, on her and the other patients. We  cannot see, but we sense, an audience watching.
Because of the speed and simplicity  of the operation, I am able, as you  are seeing, to perform the procedure  on ten patients in less than a half  hour.
Frances stares up at a fan in the ceiling. It's moving ro and round. The voice drones on.
The operation is completely painless  and can be performed without any  sedative whatsoever.
We now see vaguely that DR. HARLINGTON has moved to the  patient on the adjacent gurney.

We have always known that this form  of radical treatment was effective,  but until now it couldn't be applied  on a large scale. The old procedure  required a full day's work by a  surgical team to perform a single  operation. In the same time, working  alone, I can treat fifty.
Frances turns and stares mutely, without emotion, at what happening next to her: the leucotome (an ice-pick-like  instrument) is inserted into a woman's eye socket...
This procedure works best on patients  with extreme over-reactions to  emotional stimuli. It can also be  used as a last resort on those who  seem impervious to other forms of  treatment.
The leucotome is then shoved up into the brain and twiste
In plain language, my technique severs  the nerves which give emotional energy  to ideas. Along with the cure comes  a loss of affect... a kind of  emotional flattening...
Frances turns away and stares at the fan again. There is  something simple and pleasing about its rhythmic whirring
...with diminished creativity and  imagination. Patients become like  good solid cake with no icing. But,  after all, it is their emotions and  imaginations that are disturbed.
We glimpse the leucotome being withdrawn.
These patients will soon be leaving  the hospital.
Harlington's face moves vaguely into Frances' view.
Lobotomy gets 'em home.
He moves directly over Frances, his pleasant face obscuri the fan. As the leucotome descends, we:
Total disrepair: peeling paint, broken steps, fallen  shingles... This house is easing slowly back to nature...

Neglect is just as evident inside. Dust, faded rugs, torn yellow curtains. Lillian sits on the couch staring out a  window. She has aged and looks tiny, frail, with no trace her old formidability. The scrapbook is open on her lap.
What was I saying? Oh yes, it was  the Communists that did it to Frances.
Ernest is hunched in a chair by the stone fireplace. FOUR REPORTERS crouch on the floor, totally bored. Yesterday's headlines are now old news.
They capture the mind by first  seducing the heart. I suppose I never  taught Frances to close her heart...
Two Reporters rise and edge toward the door.
Uh... excuse us, Mrs. Farmer. We're  going to have to... uh...
(rising) Yeah, I better pack it in too.
(distractedly) Pardon? Oh, would you like more  lemonade?
The last Reporter gets to his feet.
(kindly) I think we've had enough. Thank you,  Mrs. Farmer. Goodbye.
He follows the others out. Lillian climbs wearily to her  feet and goes to the window, looks out. Ernest stares int the fire.
You know, Ernie, I think we should  have Frances' room repainted for  when she comes home. That'll brighten  her day.

Ernest looks at her wearily, as if she is stark raving ma He knows damn well Frances isn't coming home... FADE IN ON: A TELEVISION SCREEN against a dark background The show is "This Is Your Life". We SEE a smiling RALPH  EDWARDS, reading from a large black book. Next to him sta Frances. She has aged dramatically, but is still a very  handsome woman. She seems uncomfortable.

...Dwayne Steele divorced you, and  from this point on, your story takes  a darker turn. Shunned by the  Hollywood you criticized so harshly,  alienated from your family and  friends, you turn your back on  professional commitments in New York,  and alcohol and drugs enter your  life. These are sad, desperate times  for you.
Throughout this, Frances' jaw works slowly back and forth not from anger, but in embarrassment and doubt.
...until finally your mother finds  it necessary to commit you to a state  mental institution. Were you mentally  ill, Frances?
...No, Ralph. I don't believe I ever  was sick. But when you're treated  like a patient long enough, you're  apt to act like one...

We MOVE AWAY from the screen to see that the TV set is in the living room of a comfortable, tastefully furnished ho On the couch in front of the set sits Harry York. He stil looks athletic, young for his age. Tears stream down his  cheeks.
Were you an alcoholic?
No.
Were you a drug addict?
No. Never.
ON THE SCREEN Edwards has moved Frances over to a seating area where various people from Frances' life are waiting, smiling at her. We've never seen any of them before.

...and over 200 producers have been  invited to watch your appearance  here tonight... so who knows, Frances  Farmer, anything's possible on your  comeback trail! (indicating seating  area) And since your friends tell me they  have to drive you everywhere, look  what we've got for you!
The curtains behind them open to reveal a car in a spotli
A brand new 1958 Edsel!
The audience applauds. Frances smiles guardedly.
Thank you, Ralph.
Thank you, Frances. And after the  show we're hosting a reception for  you and your friends at Hollywood's  own Roosevelt Hotel!
Applause.
So, Frances Farmer, this is your  life. Good night. God bless you.
The audience applauds. Frances smiles wearily and accepts congratulations.
A group of PEOPLE are coming down the front steps, France among them. They all talk happily, Frances is silent but  smiling.
Where shall we drop you, Frances?  Home?
(vaguely) No... no, someone's picking me up.
The people all excuse themselves, calling goodbye. France waits by herself for a few moments, but soon begins to wa away down the sidewalk.
Hey.
She turns. Harry is leaning against the side of a buildin looking much as he did when they first met. But there is  very little light of recognition in Frances' eyes.
C'mere. I want to talk to you.
(flatly) Oh. Why, Harry York. How nice to see  you.
Harry is a little puzzled by her reaction.
How... how ya doin', Farmer?
Fine, thank you. Did you watch the  show?
Sure I did, that's why I'm here.
(concerned) How did I look?
Oh, you... (smiling) ...ennh.
(a glimmer, but she  does not pick up on  the cue) Well... you're looking well.
They are both silent a long moment.
I got a new car. Only it's red. Did  you know Mama died?
Yeah. Yeah, I heard about that.
Dad, too. I sold the house. I'm a  faceless sinner, Harry...
Why do you say that?
I'd ask you to take me home, but I'm  a faceless sinner. (she smiles) ...You smell good, Harry. Familiar,  you know? I'd ask you to take me  home, but...
Harry is alarmed now.
(taking her by the  arm) Frances!
She angrily bares her teeth; then just as suddenly she re and becomes lucid.
Don't get mad at me, Harry. Please.  It's just... Some things happen for  the best.

Beat. She takes his hand as if to shake it. Harry clasps hers tenderly. She holds on like an old woman, stroking his hand. For an instant she gets lost in time, just holding his hand. The she looks up.
It's going to be slow from now on.  Do you know what I mean, Harry?
I'm not sure.
Very slow. (uncertainly) But we're not going to stop, are we?
No.
(reassured) No, we're not.
It is as if she is able to express in words the last remn of her indomitable will... but the words bear no emotiona power.
Goodbye, Harry. It was very good to  see you again.
Yes. Would you like me to walk a  little way with you?
That would be okay.
Just a little way.
He offers his arm. She takes it. All rather formal. They  stroll on together.
